剧情还可以，但是真心没有时间看，音乐也不错，流程不算短但也绝对不长去除挂卡时间可能通关也就五六个小时，游戏进过HB月包，所以最好是在贴吧或者TB购买全球key，15腿的key绝对物超所值，自己感觉很合胃口，玩的很嗨，评分8.5/10！

32576407.review:
Epistory: Typing Chronicles покорила меня с самого первого момента запуска демо-версии (ура, несмотря на предупреждение в системных требованиях, на некоторых интегрированных видеокартах она без проблем идет).  В моем представлении игра (особенно, инди-игра) сделана хорошо, если по ней не видно, на чем она сделана. Вот как по OneShot не догадаться, что он создавался в RPG-Maker, так и Epistory совершенно не выглядит как «типичный продукт на Unity», и это прямо-таки чудесно. Удивительное внимание к деталям и мелочам, и подача истории, чем-то напоминающая «Bastion» (но «Bastion» когда-то показался слишком пафосным, а здесь всего в меру, возможно, из-за того, что сама история более личная). Мир разворачивается под ногами игрока, и голос повествователя рассказывает о происходящем, и его слова тут же появляются вокруг, вписанные в окружающий мир. Мир не совсем настоящий, бумажный, разворачивающийся как оригами, так что вполне естественно, что на этой бумаге кто-то делает заметки :). 

Очень здорово, что Epistory - больше, чем типичная typing game. В других знакомых мне играх со словами сюжет скорее формальный, он лишь задает игроку направление движения. Здесь есть подробности, в которые можно вникать, собирая мозаику, реконструируя произошедшее, исследуя мир. Причем ни разу за все время у меня не возникло ощущения, что я не знаю в какую сторону идти или что я случайно зашла в локацию раньше, чем это нужно было по сюжету. Кое-где порядок прохождения этапов может варьироваться, и можно возвращаться в уже посещенные места, чтобы собрать спрятанные предметы, но все это не мешает развертыванию основного сюжета. Игроку мягко указывают нужное направление: для открытия некоторых частей карты нужно набрать определенное количество очков («вдохновения» по внутренней терминологии игры), а другие становятся доступны после открытия новых возможностей атаки (стихий). Темы локации предсказуемы (подземелье, лед, механизмы, пустыня…), а их толкования временами прямолинейны, но это вовсе не делает игру скучной, а лишь помогает проникнуться историей. А еще слова, которые приходится печатать, тоже несут определенный смысл - либо они намекают на события сюжета, либо становятся частью атмсоферы локации, как названия минералов в подземелье или названия ветров в воздушных островах (ух, сколько же я теперь знаю названий ветров...) 
 
Бои мне здесь чрезвычайно понравились (возможно, потому, что в кои-то веки мне не нужно было специально что-то осваивать, чтобы показывать неплохой уровень - я и так большую часть дня занимаюсь тем, что печатаю). Основной принцип остается одним и тем же (стоишь в центре, отбиваешься от нападающих волнами противников), но благодаря тому, что по ходу игры вводятся новые виды атаки, он не надоедает. А благодаря адаптивной сложности мне уже в первых битвах было над чем потрудиться (до сих пор хожу и всем рассказываю, как на меня подло напало слово БИБЛИОГРАФОВЕДЕНИЕ). 

Управление. Поначалу оно может показаться странным - EFJI вместо привычного WASD. Оно настраиваемое, и всегда можно поставить любой удобный вариант, но не стоит с этим торопиться. Если вы печатаете десятью пальцами, EFJI может оказаться для вас более подходящим и естественным - враг может напасть неожиданно, и лучше сразу держать руки в «боевой» позиции.) В остальном оно очень логичное и продуманное. И в игровом меню, и в настройках тянуться за мышкой не придется - просто вводим с клавиатуры название нужного пункта. И еще: к концу игры вы научитесь с невероятной скоростью печатать по крайней мере четыре слова: ОГОНЬ, ЛЕД, ИСКРА и ВЕТЕР. Потому что для переключения между видами атаки (во время битвы, когда мелкие насекомые со всех сторон) нужно - вполне в духе игры - напечататть их название. 

Единственный недостаток игры в том, что она короткая (у меня на прохождение ушло немногим больше семи часов). За полную цену я бы все же не стала ее покупать, а вот со скидкой вполне.  Впрочем, небольшая продолжительность искупается проработанностью деталей, которую мне очень хочется назвать совершенством, или уж, по крайней мере, мастерством. Как оригами.  

Пойду, еще попечатаю. Я все еще не теряю надежду получить достижение за «1000 слов без ошибок подряд».

中文版出了之后立马把它从库里翻出来通关了，说一下感想
 故事讲述的是一个小女孩骑着巨大狐狸的冒险，画面非常小清新，不同迷宫里的光影效果也有点不一样，让人不容易腻。地图是靠积分解锁，每次解锁地图看着它一点点铺开然后长出景物的感觉非常棒！游戏内有一定解谜要素，不过都相当简单，纯粹是为了打字不会太无聊调剂用的

32389367.review:
在微博看到出了中文版，于是果断入手。尽管我小时候没有玩过金山的打字游戏，但是自认为打字速度还是可以的，于是虽然入手的时候就知道可以切换成拼音，但为了证明我的手速还是一直用的英文。然而打到后半段BOSS关我就萎了……换成拼音后我顿时觉得这个游戏变成了一个无双切菜游戏，随着键盘噼里啪啦的声音，一个又一个敌人灰飞烟灭什么的，那感觉简直不要太爽！主剧情通关后感觉腰有点酸（因为老是无意识驼着背盯屏幕打字，时间长了还真不好受QAQ）

优点就不说了，简单说几个在游戏过程中感受到的不足：
① 字体和字体的颜色的选择感觉不太好，有的场景字幕和地面简直融为一体，看起来很费劲（虽然都听得懂在说啥但还是想看看文字翻译得怎样_(:з」∠)_）
② 不知道是只有我这样还是其他人也遇到过，我这边输入速度过快时感觉系统经常反应不过来。比如一个大概6个字左右的单词，在我绝对是正确输入了的前提下，有时候系统会只判定我输入正确了一部分。这个让我有点恼火……（要不我早拿到那个输入1000字不错误的成就了）
③ 音乐稍微有点单调，听多了有点无感；
④ 有的场景下虫子们不是很明显，我经常跑着跑着就直接冲到虫子身上GAME OVER了（然而我根本就没看到虫子，或者发现有虫子的时候已经来不及了_(:з」∠)_）

但总体来说这款游戏还是值得一玩的，尤其适合那些对敲击键盘这件事有着特殊爱好的人们~接下来准备挑战一下竞技场，不知道什么时候才能拿齐成就呢？加油喽~

32382412.review:
GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: [u][b]87% YES[/b][/u] / 13% NO
 
[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Cute origami art style. I love how the world unfolds when you expand the areas.
[*]Great dynamic difficulty settings with options to change to a fixed difficulty if you run into a wall.
[*]Fun modifiers for text attacks that change how you approach some groups of enemies.
[*]I adore the design of the main character who rides around on a fox.
[*]Exploration feels good and gives you just enough incentive to wander around a bit before getting back to the main story.
[/list]
 
[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]Story feels non-existent, but this won't be the main focus of your experience with this game so that's fine.
[*]You may see how the game WANTS you to move your character, which is "E" (NW), "F" (SW), "I" (NE), and "J" (SE) but DON'T DO THIS! I tried to get use to this movement style but wow does it feel awful, especially when stepping carefully around floor puzzles. I didn't realize until more than halfway past the game that you can control movement with ASDW. That's my fault for not trying it out the gate, but I guess I assumed it wasn't an option since the game told me to use EFIJ.
[/list]
 
[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
A charming, short experience that features a surprisingly solid dynamic difficulty setting and adorable visuals. A solid entry in typing games that is well worth your time.

32366816.review:
De l'indé poétique et original.

Epistory est une petite perle vraiment bluffante. Graphismes en low poly, le jeu offre un visuel magnifique, notamment appuyé par sa DA nous plongeant dans un monde d'origami merveilleux, renforcé par un sound design efficace. Soutenu par une histoire à la fois poétique et triste, le jeu nous tient en haleine tout le long de l'aventure. Mais son gros point fort est son gameplay, avant tout. On en à assez d'appuyer sur une touche ou de bouger la souris pour tuer un ennemi ? Et bien taper son mot au clavier alors ! Car oui le seul moyen de tuer les ennemis dans ce jeu est de taper le mot qui se trouve au dessus d'eux, et ça peut se montrer complexe par moment, surtout quand vous vous retrouvez entouré de dizaine d'ennemis. Ce qui vous demandera de faire preuve de doigté, calme, et réflexion stratégique.

En point noir il n'y en a qu'un, à première vue : 
-Quelques longueurs dans la narration par moment.

Un bon jeu indépendant en somme.

32347165.review:
非常棒的游戏，没想到普通的打字游戏可以把内容做到这么丰富，战斗机质融合了属性相克，战斗环节做得也很棒，头一次觉得在一款打字游戏中需要玩家有一点战斗策略，不然有些地方确实会吃了点苦头，当然游戏还是有难易度的，可以照顾到打字比较一般的玩家。

+++++++++++
+游戏优点：
1.游戏美术风格很独特，少有的剪纸手工画风，颜色和光影都做得不错，纸质的质感也很明明显，很适合给喜欢听翻书页声音的人。不同自然环境的关卡设计也很好，氛围把握到位。

2.游戏系统融合得不错，魔幻类游戏的魔法技能收集、技能升级和属性相克，塔防类游戏中把握消灭怪物先后顺序的时机的策略性,以及不同关卡各自不同的解密要素，这些都大大丰富了游戏性。


-----------------
-游戏缺点：（大部分问题有可能是制作时间导致）
1.中文的魔法元素没有翻译，还是英语的spark、fire、ice、wind

1.游戏暂停页面的各项ui设计，插图，载入页面都显得有些简陋，和游戏主画面不搭

2.地图页面比较差劲，每次查看地图时只能在大地图和小地图来回切换，地图不能滚轮缩放，也不能平移。而且地图的绘制也很粗糙，和精美的游戏视角相差有一段距离

3.中文旁白的文字有些和环境过于融合，有点看不清，并且剧情和主角内心情绪比较难体验到，基本上在探索地图的时候都忽略了，文字放置的位置不够好，经常要放慢脚步看文字，有点影响探索的节奏

4.地图传送虽说很快但有点简陋，没有任何特效或过渡


总而言之，这还是一款比较不错的独立游戏，有可能因为时间和资金导致游戏存在一些问题，但这些问题基本上都不是致命问题，估计制作组把绝大多数时间和精力都花在了主要的游戏画面、关卡设计和游戏系统上，这是值得赞赏的，毕竟游戏的主干是结实的，那这个游戏基本就不会差到哪里去，感谢制作组做出这么有趣的游戏，期待你们下一部作品。

32340177.review:
I really loved this game!

The gameplay concept (typing to interact with the game) is what first appealed to me, as I learned 10 finger typing and don't get many chances to apply that knowledge. So I thought this would be a fun way to test my typing skills, speed and accuracy... and I was not wrong. :)

At first, it was a bit challenging getting used to controlling the fox using EFJI instead of WASD, but I decided to stick to it (the game does give you the option to use WASD if you want) and it felt really natural after a while and, if you know how to type using all your 10 fingers, it also helps you already have your fingers in position for typing.

However, if you're not a professional typer, don't be alarmed! The game does have an Adaptative mode that will pretty much learn what your typing speed is and adjust the difficulty accordingly, so that everyone can enjoy this masterpiece.

I really liked everything about the game. The original concept, the gameplay, the graphics and soundtrack, the ocasional narrations, the little puzzles inside the dungeon areas. Even the fact that, after beating the game, you can still go back and continue to explore the map at will (especially useful if you're hunting down all the Steam achievements).

Can't really think of anything that I would change in this title.

10/10

32330568.review:
I really think this should be a good game. Unforunately the control scheme is crap. EFIJ is what you use to move around. Alternatively you could use the arrow keys, but they do not move with the isometric view of the board; so you have to always hit 2 keys to move. Good luck moving then switching to typing as some parts of the game require twitch gameplay. It's so sad because I like this game, I just hate the way you move.

The most challenging part of this whole game has been my brain trying to remember that "I" is right and "J" is down... Or is it "J" is right... DANGIT! I went the wrong way on this one way ice again!!!

I also followed the mod instructions, since the game doesn't allow you to set up your own control scheme from, say, an in-game menu. I downloaded the control file, modified the keyboard inputs, loaded up the game, selected my mod... and it fixed nothing! I tried to use ESDF to function like EFIJ, but there was something wrong. The LEFTDOWN "S" and RIGHTDOWN "D" controls did not function as intended.  Why? BECAUSE the WASD controls overwrite the controls I had entered in the above control scheme! OMG.  Why do I have to go through so much effort just to make a game control the way it honestly should have worked out of the box?

I like this game, and I'll keep playing now that I've spent 3 hours frustrated with the controls and another full hour trying to fix the game. But honestly, I can't recommend this to my friends. Sorry

32311614.review:
首先感谢 [url=https://cowlevel.net/wildrose] 奶牛关：野蔷薇[/url] 以及本作开发商提供的key。
野蔷薇这么多可供申请的游戏我目前就只对这个游戏产生了兴趣，后面游玩的实际体验也证实了我的选择是正确的。完整图文评测请 [url=https://cowlevel.net/game/Epistory_Typing_Chronicles/review/2463860] 点此[/url] 

[h1]1. 太长不看[/h1]
针对太长不看的人，我简单给出整体分数以及pros & cons：

    [b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
    [*]有中文字幕；
    [*]清新的、独具特色的画面风格；
    [*]优秀的、节奏感强的配乐；
    [*]字幕与地形的巧妙结合；
    [*]巨大的地图、良好的玩家引导；
    [*]精简却恰到好处的技能树；
    [*]新颖的操作方式以及玩法。
[/list]

    [b] Cons: [/b]
[list]
    [*]重复的流程；
    [*]部分战斗难度不平衡；
    [*]中文字体不符合整体风格；
    [*]偶尔发生打字延迟。
[/list]

[b]总体评分：[/b] 8.5/10

[h1]2. 详细评测：[/h1]
《秘镜奇缘：字谜编年史》是一款真正意义上的独立游戏。

[b]玩法[/b]
如今在steam中的独立游戏，大多是像素风、low-poly、类rogue、生存题材为主的类似玩法作品，虽然形式很讨喜，也确实好玩，但长期接触下来，未免会产生视觉疲劳。这时候就很需要有一种无论是玩法上还是视觉风格上都有所创新的作品出来，给玩家换换口味。《秘境奇缘》就是这样一款游戏。事实上如今要说新奇的玩法，还真是乏善可陈，而以打字为主要玩法的游戏则更是屈指可数。小时候玩过的《金山打字通》自然算是接触的这类游戏的鼻祖，但它主要是以练习打字为主要目的，带有比较强的目的性，因此在游戏性上是差强人意的。
《秘镜奇缘》很好的平衡了打字这一功能性行为和游戏之间的平衡，通过打字来清除障碍、杀怪、解锁地图，把敲打键盘的节奏感很好的带入到战斗中，加上具有感染力的配乐，可以说充分的发掘出了键盘的可玩性。在游戏的背景上采用的是奇幻式的故事设定，引入了火、冰、电、风等魔法属性，给单纯的敲键盘增添了一份技巧性。
在《秘镜奇缘》中的这片魔法大陆上，玩家不仅需要面对各种怪物，还有很多谜题需要动脑去解决。本作的解谜要素也以打字为主，种类不算多，难度也不会很高，但都充分运用了地形上的安排，也颇有柳暗花明的感觉。

[b]美术风格[/b]
《秘镜奇缘》的美术风格，初看有点类似ps4上的《撕纸小邮差》，实际给我的感觉是融合了Low-poly以及纸质风格，在动画上采用的是立体书的弹出效果，可以算是独具特色，只此一家。另外本作虽然地图很大，但需要玩家通过不断探索积累经验值逐步解锁，因此不会给人毫无头绪的乱逛的感觉。每块地域都各有特色，地形种类上也很丰富，在各个魔法的获取地点都会和魔法的种类相呼应。要说不足的话，可能就是怪的种类太过单一，给人感觉不管是在哪一关，都只有那么几种固定种类。
另外值得一提的是环境音效很丰富，能给人置身丛林或荒野的感觉；战斗场景的配乐虽然很棒，能充分调动玩家的情绪，但从头到尾也只有一种，长时间玩下来的话，也未免有种单调的感觉。

[b]剧情[/b]
因为尚未通关，所以剧情方面暂时不做评价

[b]总体印象[/b]
《秘镜奇缘：字谜编年史》是今年我玩到的最独特的独立游戏，虽然仍有一些不满意的地方，但总体上来说绝对称得上佳作。

32264199.review:
Epistory – Typing Chronicles est un jeu avec un style graphique on se régale devant ces décors en origami qui se révèle à nous au fur et à mesure de notre progression.

Les ennemies, des insectes, valent eux-aussi le détour même si on peut regretter un certain manque de variété dans le bestiaire après 4-5 heures d’exploration.

Le jeu se contrôle au clavier, on utilise les touches ZQSD pour se déplacer et on appuis ensuite sur la touche Entrée pour saisir les mots. On peut également commencer un mot et en changer dans la foulée si l’on se rend compte que le danger vient d’une autre créature.

Epistory – Typing Chronicles est d’ailleurs plutôt bien fait au niveau de sa présentation des nouvelles mécaniques de jeu.

Je ne le conseille toutefois pas aux plus jeunes car la difficulté est réelle et il faut être bien attentif à ce qui arrive sur notre héroïne.

32245523.review:
C'est vraiment un bon moment à passer, élégant, poétique, onirique. On se prend vraiment à ces joutes d’écritures ; on apprécie ces décors en papier qui s’ouvrent devant nous. Il y a une belle identité artistique.

Quelques remarques : j’ai joué en disposition BÉPO et j’en suis fort heureux vu le nombre de mots, parfois tarabiscotés, qu’il faut frapper ! Je pense qu’il faut vraiment utiliser tous ses petits doigts de dactylo pour profiter pleinement du jeu, et je ne saurais que vous encourager à bien placer vos petites mains : ça fait un bon exercice de frappe au clavier au passage :) 

La prise en main conseillée des déplacements du renard n’est pas évidente du tout cependant (index-majeur de chaque main), mais on fini tant bien que mal par s’y habituer.

Il y a des «nids» d’insectes, sorte d’épreuves avec de nombreux insectes (et donc de nombreux mots à transposer) qui ne sont pas forcément très évidentes. En fait le jeu s’adapte à votre vitesse de frappe, et du coup, plus on va vite… plus il faut écrire vite ! Ça met un peu de tension dans cet univers plutôt calme et apaisant dans l’ensemble…

J’ai trouvé également sympathique et bien pensé le dévérouillage des succès "1%" : au fil de l’aventure, à force d’écrire des mots, on obtient des succès tel que «1% de Crimes et Châtiments», qui indiquent… bien… voilà… vous avez compris je suis sûr :) C'est tout de même une tournure bien plus originale que «Écrire plus de 1000 mots» !

This is a must-play if you are interested in Typing stuff, this game will surely improve your typing speed, and there is no violent feature whatsoever in game so it is suitable for all kinds of people.

You expand the map by exploring the world, you gain lots of collectable stuff and turn wastelands into forests by typing. And it is quite challenging when you go to the nests of your enemies in game, you have to type as fast as possible to beat all of your enemies which is a lot of fun and moreover you practice your typing speed during the process and improve your vocabulary even. And what else surprised me is that it even has Chinese gameplay language in game! So don't worry if you type too slow in English, it might includes your native language in game.

pros:
+ beneficial for all kinds of ppl
+ nice graphics
+ a big world that worths exploring
+ interesting narrative style

cons:

This is the best I can explaing this game:  You are playing as a young girl who rides on the back of a fox.  The entire world is built on stories with the landscape looking like origami artwork  and an overarching story developing as you play.  You cast spells to fight monsters by typing out the word or words that they have hovering over them. 32224720.review:
[h1] 책 속에서 펼쳐지는 소녀와 여우의 모험 [/h1]

세상에 홀로 남겨진 자기 이름도 기억 못하는 소녀와 여우가 생존자를 찾아다니며, 홀로 맞서 싸우기 위해 여러가지 원소마법을 얻게된다는 이야기입니다. 점점 진행하다 보면 정체성을 깨닫게 되죠. 엔딩을 보면 이 모든 것은 초석이었다는 것을 깨닫지만...


마치 동화책을 한장 한장 넘긴 것처럼 전개되는 효과로  스테이지가 넘어갈때 종이 한 장씩 촤르르르륵~ 하고 넘어가며, 종이로 오브젝트가 만들어진 것처럼 눈과 귀를 호강시켜 줍니다.


영알못이라면, 타이핑+엄청난 분위기 있는 게임을 그런갑다~ 하고 즐기시면 되고, 영잘알일 경우 스토리 풀어내는 능력이 대단하다는 걸 느낍니다.

이게 우리나라 언어로도 출시가 되었다면, 갓겜 중 갓겜이라고 칭송 받았을 겁니다.
마치 동화책을 구연해주는 나래이션과 주인공 소녀는 글씨와 함께 풀 보이스가 지원되는데, 영어 동화책을 읽는듯한 느낌을 가져다 줍니다. 스토리 풀어내는 능력만 봤을땐 4~5만원 짜리 게임 같네요.


게임측면을 보자면, 퍼즐 어드벤쳐와 타이핑을 섞어놓은 게임인데, 길 찾는 난도와 게임난도는 그렇게 어렵진 않아서 입문자용으로 제격입니다. 역시 어드벤쳐 답게 시야제한 스테이지가 존재 하지만, 그냥 동화 애니메이션 정도의 무서운 정도로 가볍고 EQ 발산하며 플레이가 가능합니다.


이 게임은 특이하게도 나침반 모양의 오브젝트를 밟아서 스테이지를 확장시키는 개념인데, 일정 경험치가 도달해야 활성화가 가능하며, 후반부 히든 스테이지는 다소 강한 필요량을 보이긴 하나, 처음부터 히든스테이지 돌다보면 어렵지 않게 만렙이 되어 쉽게 출입이 가능해집니다. 스테이지 디자인에 소름 돋았음.


[h1] evo score[/h1]


1점 : 이게 게임이냐? 그냥 적선해달라고 하지?
2점 : 이거...즐기라고 해놓은건 맞지?
3점 : 그냥 저냥 시간 떼우기로 즐길 수 있는 게임.
4점 : 정가로 주고 사도 손색이 없을만한 게임
5점 : 1000시간을 하고 싶을정도로 이 게임을 영원히 지속시키고 싶다.

4.1/ 5


P.S 50%에 8,000원에 샀는데 감자탕 먹는 것마냥  아주 등골 뽑아먹다 못해 부숴서 힘줄까지 후르륵 마시는 기분입니다.
퍼즐 어드벤쳐라 액션성은 그다지 좋지 않지만, 스토리와 이펙트를 보며 잠시 쉬어가는 게임이 되었으면 좋겠네요.

31978394.review:
I was very surprised by how much I liked this game. I came into it thinking it was going to be a "Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing" mixed with "Typing of the Dead" and it completely surpassed my expectations. The story was good and the combat is fun and frantic, especially if you are not a quick keyboard warrior! 

A few minor annoyances is that the enemies and the words get lost in the scenery (especially in the desert world) very quickly. I died a couple times from enemies I didn't see that were the same color as the background. I also would have added a checkpoint feature on the easy playthrough for those that need it because losing in a final wave only to have to start from the beginning could be frustrating for those that do not have the typing ability needed. I found that it made me more determined to tackle the wave and beat it but I had a friend try it and they were defeated that they needed to start from the beginning wave again. Just a thought! 

All the elemental powers have their unique uses in the adventuring part of the game and 3 of them have unique uses in battle (the wind power has no use when the other abilities have knockback added to them so it effectively becomes useless).

The storytelling was great and I had an overall great experience. I would definitely recommend this for anyone, children to adults, and hope that we get a sequel or another version/story with more of the same with a hair more touch of polish and new features and mechanics. 

4 out of 5.

31854323.review:
This is a very pretty & polished game with clever game-play ideas that are well executed.  It's a game where you have to quickly type words to defeat enemies and interact with the environment.  

But it's not just mindless typing.  The game adds elemental magic that greatly increases your tactical options.  Do you want to use fire magic that burns enemies faster?  Ice that slows down the enemies bearing down on you?  Lightning that can strike multiple foes if you use it correctly?  And the elemental modes and enemy variation are well balanced so that it's actually worth the trouble to think strategically moment-to-moment about which elemental mode is best depending on which enemies are attacking and which directions they are coming from.

The game has an option to adapt to your typing speed. I played with it on and I found the game  consistently challenging but not frustrating.

The little dungeons have more puzzles than I would have expected - not difficult, but engaging.  And the pop-up book style artwork looks great. I enjoyed it.

31803180.review:
Epistory - Typing Chronicles is an unique action adventure/typing game hybrid. You control a girl riding a strange fox and explore a gorgeous origami world. Since this is a typing game, all your actions (apart from movement) are performed by typing words.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The visuals in Epistory are gorgeous and easily the best aspect of the game. The origami art looks superb, especially when new areas are revealed.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The soundtrack is quite nice and the voice acting is solid too. Unfortunately there are some issues with the ambient sounds as some of them are extremely loud compared to the rest of the sound effects and there's no separate volume adjustment for ambient sounds.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Unfortunately the gameplay is rather shallow. The battles are pretty much a pure test of your typing skills. Picking the right spell adds some limited tactical depth, but overall I feel the game could have done much more with the concept.

There are some simple puzzles to solve too, but overall I didn't find the puzzle and exploration aspects of the game particularly satisfying.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
The game offers a number of different difficulty levels, including adaptive difficulty (based on your measured typing speed). These should cover a wide variety of typing speeds.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls aren't particularly great and it's rather easy to get stuck in the scenery. In practice this isn't as bad as it sounds since most of your playtime will be spent typing.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The story is rather vague and not particularly enjoyable. The writing is surprisingly weak too considering the subject matter.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
While I did not encounter any major issues, the game has lots of small glitches and feels rather unpolished. For example enemies sometimes get stuck in the scenery and some of the puzzles suffer from glitches.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Personally I found Epistory - Typing Chronicles a rather disappointing experience. The presentation is great but the gameplay is quite shallow and overall the game feels unpolished. I didn't find the game particularly fun and I wouldn't recommend it unless you are a big fan of typing games.

I played through the game on normal difficulty (with adaptive difficulty turned off). This took me around 5.5 hours.

31802989.review: Stunning Art, wonderful narrative, and you're improving your skills without even realizing it.  It's fun to explore, and it's relaxing for me somehow.  The environment in it's own way is stunning, and how it folds out before you . . .  I would suggest if you're even considering buying this game to go ahead and do it.

31796973.review:
(Edit: for some reason, the bullet-formatting doesn't show up in Steam's Review 'quick-view', so if you want to read the review, but also want to avoid large blocks of text mashed together, you can click on the review itself, and the opened page should show the bullets properly!)

[b]Summary:[/b] Epistory - Typing Chronicles is, not so surprisingly, a typing game at heart, combined with aspects from your typical progression-based RPG, along with some basic puzzle-solving ingredients as well. The world consists of a relatively large, multi-biome hub that connects the game's levels together, though you only have access to a percentage of the hub at the beginning of the game, and unlock access to more of it as you progress.

[b]Story:[/b] Since the story revolves around the main character re-learning lost memories as the story goes on, I will do my best not to spoil anything there. In a nutshell, however, you play as a young female antagonist who rides a large pet fox, that serves as your main form of transportation throughout the game, battling insectoid enemies with typing-based combat, and earning 'points / experience' to level up various perks that make the main character faster & more powerful.

[b]Combat:[/b] As mentioned earlier, you fight the insect enemies you come across in your travels by entering into a typing mini-game when they appear. The insects slowly approach your character, but can be defeated by typing words that will show up above their heads. Again, I don't want to spoil too much here since they are unlocked as you progress with the story, but there are four "elements" that all have some benefit within combat (some enemies can only be damaged by a specific element type). These same elements are also required in order to open up more areas of the main hub.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] [b]Art:[/b] The story-book, origami-esque artstyle is both beautifully done (aesthetically-speaking), and also helps to tie a lot of things together in the game thematically (Hopefully there are some good screenshots out there to give you an idea of what I'm describing). To give you a quick mental picture to those who have also seen the movie, I just recently watched 'Kubo and the Two Strings', and the art-style was immediately reminiscent of my experiences with this game (and I mean that as a very good thing!).
[*] [b]Unique Game Genre:[/b] IMO, there aren't a ton of good word-building / typing games on Steam, and so it was really refreshing to play one that was (Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey is another one of my favorite word-game / RPG crosses).
[*] [b]Non-Linearity (a):[/b] After you successfully complete a few of the beginning levels, you start to unlock additional areas by walking onto glowing circles scattered throughout the hub, provided you have met the circle's listed "point" requirement (continued below).
[*] [b]Score Chaining:[/b] These points can be found in treasure chests scattered throughout the game's world, but will primarily be earned by chaining together successful [typing kills?]. As mentioned earlier, words appear above the heads of enemies, but also above numerous inanimate objects scattered throughout the hub & the levels. After the player scores points for successfully typing any of these words, a countdown timer will appear, during which the player can chain together additional [typing kills?] to essentially receive a score multiplier and also refresh the timer back to full. [*] [b]Non-Linearity (b):[/b] There is absolutely no requirement to move quickly to chain scores together, but I found that chaining large scores together rewards the Player with the ability to access additional sections of the main hub earlier than otherwise would be possible, thereby allowing for multiple progression paths (and hence the 'non-linearity' tag!). I thought that was a really cool game mechanic on the part of the developers!
[*] [b]Little Details:[/b] The words that show up above both enemies and inanimate objects have some relation to the object themselves (e.g. there might be a tree blocking the main path that requires typing "birch" to remove, or a fire pylon that needs to be lit by typing "pyromaniac", etc.). There are a number of other small touches like that scattered throughout the game, and they all help to give the title character!
[*] [b]Difficulty:[/b] There is an option to have the difficulty scale with the Player's typing ability, so while the combat mini-games started out very easy, the game successfully scaled the difficulty up to what I thought was an appropriate level (see second-thought in cons).
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] [b]Difficulty:[/b] I honestly didn't see it as a con personally, but I think a lot of experienced typers will find the game a bit too easy. To me, Epistory was a game I played when I wanted to relax and simply explore the in-game world, and so I appreciated that it wasn't frustratingly difficult, but I think it's still worth listing here.
[*] [b]Story:[/b] Again, a minor con, but one that bears mentioning. There is [i]a[/i] story within the game, but it's delivered in a somewhat cryptic / disjointed narrative. Again, the main character is trying to regain lost memories, so I recognize that this might have been an intentional design element to fit with the theme, but I found myself lost in trying to follow the story on many occasions (especially if there were gaps in between my playtimes).
[*] [b]On-Screen Clutter:[/b] A lot of enemies require multiple words typed before they die (which is synonymous with a bulky enemy in your typical RPG). In a nice touch, the game shows 2-3 words from the list required to kill these enemies (above their heads still), highlighting / bolding the top-list required word, but also showing the next couple of words in the list in smaller lettering, which helps the Player micromanage which enemies to "aim for" in the approaching waves. This is an awesome feature on moderate-difficulty waves, but on the harder ones, the screen fills up with baddies really quick, and when they start to condense in a small area around your character, the word lists can sometimes overlap, which makes knowing what word goes with which enemy difficult at times. Not that you want the enemies that close to your character to begin with, but I definitely recall feeling like I got gipped in a few of my deaths that way. Fortunately, this problem was fairly rare, but still worth mentioning.
[*] [b]Movement:[/b] The controls on some of the ice levels got frustrating at times. Sections of the ice biome follow the classic "move-onto-ice-and-keep-sliding-in-that-direction-until-you-hit-an-object" scheme, which isn't an issue at all by itself, but with isometric controls, I found myself sometimes repeatedly going in a direction that I did not want to go in.
[*] [b]Replayability:[/b] Really not much of a con at all, because I felt that I received much more than my money's worth, but after completing the main story, I don't personally feel a lot of incentive to pick the game back up. There is an endless-enemy-wave arena mode with online scoreboards that you can test your skills on, that seems like it could be pretty neat if that's your thing, but it just didn't appeal to me all that much.
[/list]

[b] Bottom Line:[/b] In my opinion, the Pros largely outweigh the cons in Epistory, so if you like typing games, or unique RPG's, you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not picking this one up! (And even for those new to the genre, I think there are still a number of things that will satisfy -- enough so that the game is still worth a shot!)

31763785.review:
Epistory is a beatiful game with a nice narrative for people that want to practice their typing skills in a fun and entertaining way. 

The game is split into two separate subgames: One is the story mode where you control a little girl on her fox (with three tails! ;)) that needs to find out who she is and where she belongs and the other is an arena battle that pits you against some monsters in different surroundings with no story and no moving around. You play in a third person isometric perspective.

In the story mode you get to explore a wonderous world that gets introduced by an off screen observer whenever you enter new areas. You have to unlock each area by accumulating enough points and then standing in a marked location and the world will literally unfold in front of your eyes (a very nice effect). 

Within that world you will find inanimate objects that you can destroy by just typing the words associated with them but also monsters that will come your way and try to kill you to pose a time challenge. Once in a while you will find a "nest" which is basically a local battle arena where you are locked in one place, monsters come at you from all sides and you have to survive for a few waves to complete an area or find something special. 

The game works with a skill system that allows you to spend points whenever you level up. The skills you get to spend your points on have to be unlocked first and will include different ways to eliminate your enemies (and some enemies can only be eliminated by certain skills and some traps will also only be solvable with certain skills). Some of the skillsets are nicely worked into the world by appearing as a foreign language that you can't type when you don't have the skill required.

There is also a combo system that allows you to score more points the longer you manage to eliminate new challenges within a certain time. The timer gets pushed back a little with every enemy or thing you eliminate making really long combo chains possible - it gets a bit hecktick though and you have to time certain attacks in the right way so to not kill your enemies before you know where your next target will be otherwise you will loose your combo waiting for new monsters ;)

Sadly the story mode can be completed within a day if your typing skills are medium to high but the story and the world are going to make it a very entertaining day. For those that are not typing that fast: The game has an adaptive difficulty and battles never feel as difficult if you manage to die in one.

The arena mode is a never ending slugfest of monsters. It can be lots of fun and it will test your typing skills much more than the actual game with waves getting more and more dangerous.

Although I really enjoyed plaing the game there are two things that I didn't like so much:
a) story mode is too short and not really challenging (a minor complaint - there is still enough, I just would have liked more)
b) the character controls. I repeatedly ran into the wrong direction because the controls were so unfamilliar and in my opinion unintuitive. If they would have turned the directions by 45° I would have been so much happier with the game ;)

I recommended the game to the rest of my family and am happy that I bought it.

31681270.review:
A very enjoyable typing game.

Pros:
+ Fun to play
+ Good gameplay
+ Addictive in a good way
+ Typing does not feel meaningless (there is some correlation with the words you type and the task you perform)
+ Nice graphics
+ Improve your typing skills...

Cons:
- ...yet only slightly
- There is no actual story
- Repetitive and not diversified enough
- Tedious achievements
- Short
- Not enough upgrades (XP points become useless quite early in the game)

Verdict: Totally recommended.

If you don't mind typing, you'd better buy it! Maybe on sale though. And the soundtrack is not worth it. 

Long version:

This game alternates between exploratory phases and fighting phases. During exploratory phases you travel a paper world which unfolds as you stride, in a way much reminiscent of Bastion. The narrative follows you and is integrated to this exploration (once more, much like Bastion). As you explore, you are mainly looking for chests which bring more XP and collectibles in some levels (art gallery items). There are also some very light puzzles to solve, and environment items you can interact with by typing (you can make flowers by blossom, or you can make wood log disappear). And you can stumble upon nests, which lead to a fight sequence.

Fight sequences are very enjoyable. Insects (worms, spiders, snakes ; okay none of them are insects, but they are called like this in the game) come from different sides of the arena, on a wave-based pattern (if you didn't finish the wave the next one does not appear). If they reach the center of the arena where you stand, you die and have to start the fight again. You kill the insects by typing the words written above them. 

A very nice thing is that you have four elemental powers. Each of them have a different effect on the insects you strike and give you an edge. Fire will burn the next word, ice will freeze your foe, etc. Some insects are also of a certain color and can be killed only if you strike them with the right elemental power. This adds some fun variety, but it feels unexploited somehow. As a general rule, all fights are pretty much alike.

This, I think, is one of the main drawbacks of the game. It is well done, fun to play, but you always repeat the same things over and over. Explore a little but, open some chests, wipe a nest, enter a new area, explore, solve puzzles, wipe another nest. At least, each different level have a distinct graphical touch which breaks a little bit the gameplay monotony.  Also, there are no quests and you have no incentive to revisit an area once you found it. The game would have been much greater in my opinion if there had been some additional tasks to perform, or interesting items to dig up. 

Killing insects give you XP. You can then buy some upgrades, but usually, you have bought all available upgrades before unlocking new ones, so there is a limited amount of choice in this. XP become thus useless quite early in the game. Unfortunately, gaining new XP and unlocking new abilities could have been a nice incentive to go on even after the end of the story. The only reason left to do so is to unlock the remaining, tedious achievements (e.g. kill 10,000 insects while the counter would be around 2,000 at the end of the story). 

Now let's turn to the other main drawback of the game: the story. The game is really really nice, everything has been well thought out, and yet, there is no actual story. There is some narrative line, half allegorical, which ends with some poor 'revelation' (don't expect anything) which withdraws all meaning from the game. It's just about wiping worms nests, basically. This is quite sad as the game would have greatly benefit from a nice story. It almost calls for a nice story, as the tone of the game is delicate, a little precious, so that a proper narrative seems a requirement. Unfortunately this is not the case.

So, Epistory is a nice little game, carefully polished, with charm and qualities, but it could have been much greater with few additions. It is this kind of game for which I wish there would be a DLC - adding some items inside chests, for instance, some lore in the universe, some mystery, I don't know. For in this state, the game leaves a feeling of disappointment, of something unfulfilled, which is quite sad.

31293954.review:
(spoiler free)
+++
*Looks: the game is just stunning in visuals, most of the areas were so beautiful, i stopped for a moment to appreciate it.
*Gameplay: plays well, the "typing" part is well implemented where you switch between 4 elements: ice, fire, spark(electricity) and wind.
The game is pretty straight forward in gameplay, you always know where to go and what to do, never got stuck on anything.
Puzzles are pretty easy but that compensates the difficulty of the "fighting" parts, but ill get to that later in what i didnt like.
*Story: is well told, you cannot expect Witcher 3 level of story....duh. But the game is more focused on being beautiful then on you getting into the story "Oh i need to see what happens next in the story!!" if you understand what i mean.
*Leveling up: You dont level up too quick, too slow, just quick enough so you finish last upgrade before the ending. 
*Getting better at typing: even in the short time you can quickly learn the layout of keyboard and write without looking, because the game makes you look at the screen to see the enemies/what to write and then you have to quickly write it.
My personal stats after ending: 43 words per minute (in fight mode probably), 3600 total written words, 15900 written letters and 75 word streak without missing.
*Lenght: about 7hrs, average amout for a game like this.
*quite a bit of different enemies: different  bugs and stuff like that, bosses werent really consisted of a lot of words, they had 2-4 very hard to type words (you can expoit that a bit, more in --- section)

---
*Fighting system is too hard for some people: i mean, i can type quick, but the game was so rough for me at times i had to use Cheat Engine to slow down to game..... on easy difficulty....
*Bosses: as i mentioned before, bossed werent consisted of typing a lot of medium-difficulty words, but 2-4 very hard to type words, and when you used the fire ability on them you only had to write 2 of 4 words, because the other 2 burned using a sort of on fire debuff.
*achievements.... at the end of the game (after 7hrs) i had about 1,300 enemies killed and one of the achievements is to kill 10,000 enemies, you can do it by using an "Arena" mode in the menu but it would take ages to do.

The game itself is great, and was definetelly worth spending meney on (bought in a G2A bundle, 5 games for 3 dollars). It really tries to be more of an experience then a game, and it does well at that, but then the hard "tover defense" parts come around and flip the idea.

i think, solid 8/10

31239503.review:
It’s all very pretty, but not as pretty as I think it ought to be. For some reason the characters appear very scratchy, which I think is a result of having been designed to look much better when seen closer up, and not well surviving the distant camera necessary for letting you see the wor(l)d around you. However, the presentation is undeniably lovely. As you roam around, the esoteric story is told by a narrator, with the words appearing as text on the land. Typed letters go black and then completed words fade away, with additional magical abilities adding further effects to the mix. Fire, for instance, means every other word for an enemy will burn away, allowing you to take on multiple encroaching bads by judiciously typing on one, then another, then another, balancing their deaths before they getcha.

To prevent your travelling too far, too soon (and as such presumably to prevent your seeing the whole of the moon), different coloured words are in different unknown languages – only when you’ve learned the language will they appear in English, meaning you need to solve one area to progress to the others, each sprawling out from the central starting area. There are also sections that will only appear once you’ve scored enough points, which is a lot less elegant, but again ensures the game opens up as you’re ready for it.

Rather brilliantly, this isn’t limited to QWERTY keyboards, either. It supports AZERTY, QWERTZ, DVORAK, COLEMAK, WORKMAN, NEO2 and BEPO, and comes with adaptive difficulty if it recognises you’re banging out the words too quickly. Words are often thematically linked to whatever they’re attached to, sometimes amusingly, giving the game a sense of curation rather than just being a series of random typing tasks.

Whether it actually improves your typing I’m not sure, but it gives you statistics on your speed and so on, which you can compare before and after I guess. I’d not see the game that way at all, though, and instead recognise it as a novel (fnarr) way to play a cute, gentle third-person action RPG.

It really is a lovely thing, offering a good amount of game for a tenner, rising above its own gimmick to be a little bit special.

Truly beautiful game, not only visually, but also from the point of narration, premise and gameplay. "Epistory - Typing Chronicles" is an allegory for creative process and it works perfectly. It's not very challenging, but it's definitely addicting. It has amazing atmosphere, good voice acting and sounds in general. Puzzles are not difficult (actually most of them seemed a bit too easy), but if you get lost often (I know I do) you may get frustrated with later levels, since there's a little bit of backtracking and few times I was wondering around without a sense of what I'm suppose to do. 

Also, a word of advice: difficulty of typing depends, obviously, on language. Playing in English was way more easy that playing in Polish (my native language), because of letters like: ą, ę, ć etc., which are easier to miss, since you have to press two keys at once (not that important for the gameplay itself, but if you want to get all achievements, English is the way to go).

I strongly recommend this game.

Long Version
~~~~~~~~~~~
Have you ever heard of the term "Hidden Gem"?. Well this is what one would consider exactly that, a Hidden Gem.

it has all the mechanics of a -GOOD- GAME. What do i mean when i say a good game? Well.. I'll tell you!:

*Typing as a mechanic
*Beautiful yet simple graphics
*Emotionally-Laden narrative story
*Incentives to explore

i also need to talk to you about the second part of the game. Score. Score is not just a thing in arcades for you to get a high score. it is actually something very well made. you have to get a certain score in order to progress in the game, but also, you also need to get a certain score in order for you to upgrade your skills (and there are more then you think). 


Which also ties into the other part i spoke above. Incentive to explore. You need to explore. If you want to have an easiER time in this game, you need to explore in order to upgrade your character's skills and abilities. its so beautifully made, i think i might cry.



YOU, GET THIS GAME NOW!... if not, at least get the demo!

31094105.review:
D'habitude, je ne suis pas client de ce genre de jeux - entendez par là le typing-game. C'est donc avec un oeil presque neuf (ma seule expérience se résume à [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198164382571/recommended/583760][i][b]Slash It[/b][/i][/url]) que j'ai découvert l'univers d'[i][b]Epistory[/b][/i]. Et, pour tout dire, l'aventure m'a vraiment séduit !

Entre une direction artistique stylisée, façon origami, et un environnement sonore immersif, que ce soit grâce au doublage, aux bruitages et musiques, toutes et tous d'excellente facture, difficile d'y rester indifférent. Nul doute qu'[i][b]Epistory[/b][/i] possède une identité marquée ; sinon une âme, tant il est empreint de poésie. On pourrait craindre que ce panorama à plus d'un titre fantastique soit au service du gameplay. Détrompez-vous, il n'est aucunement question de faire-valoir ! Ici, il s'agit  plutôt d'un équilibre subtil entre fond et forme, exercice ô combien délicat.

Un typing-game, donc, qui pousse le vice jusqu'à pouvoir sélectionner l'intégralité ou presque des menus au clavier. Bref, l'idée est donc d'écrire des mots, plus ou moins longs (jusqu'à une douzaine de lettres) et plus ou moins nombreux, afin de se débarrasser d'ennemis et d'éléments du décor (voire de modifier leur état, j'y reviendrai) : buissons, ronces, rochers et autres trésors. Chacun d'eux vous rapportera une quantité variable d'expérience, selon votre degré d'efficacité. Non seulement cette expérience conditionnera votre avancée sur la carte, mais elle permettra aussi d'améliorer divers attributs : durée des combos, recul de l'assaillant à chaque mot frappé, vitesse de déplacement ou encore affichage sur la map d'informations particulières.

Comme je le disais, on pourra altérer certains composants du décor, qu'ils soient liés ou non aux quatre pouvoirs magiques que l'aventure mettra sur votre chemin : feu, glace, foudre et vent. Par exemple, il sera possible de raviver un brasero ou de faire scintiller des cristaux ; faute de quoi vous ne verrez pas l'ennemi venir. Et, il ne me semble pas l'avoir précisé, un contact, un seul, avec l'un d'entre eux est synonyme de mort... Autant dire qu'[i][b]Epistory[/b][/i] n'est pas particulièrement tendre avec les mous du [strike]genou[/strike] doigt. Geler des étendues d'eau, activer des mécanismes basés sur l'électricité ou le vent, voilà ce à quoi vous aurez parfois recours pour atteindre des endroits autrement inaccessibles.

Ces quatre éléments auront aussi un impact notable sur les combats. En effet, une partie des ennemis ne sera sensible qu'à l'un d'eux. Et ça ne s'arrête pas là : chacun possède un effet supplémentaire ! Que l'on pourra bien sûr améliorer via l'expérience. Ecrivez un mot avec le feu, le suivant se consumera alors peu à peu. Avec la glace, la créature sera gelée quelques secondes. La foudre caracolera de monstre en monstre en leur supprimant un mot à chaque rebond. Et le vent, lui, repoussera l'ennemi au loin. Bref, tout ceci est très ingénieux et fort bien exploité.

Vous l'aurez compris, à l'évidence, [i][b]Epistory[/b][/i] m'a conquis : gameplay, ambiance, tout y est.

[h1]Verdict : 4,5/5 - Excellent, à acheter les yeux fermés ![/h1]

Amazing little game with great art, style, and soundtrack!

The concept (typing-based combat) has a lot more complexity than you'd expect, especially towards the latter part of the game. While the game's difficulty is adaptive by default, if you're a competent touch typist I recommend just setting it to max.

The words aren't chosen at random from a dictionary either - they're linked to the actual things and creatures in the game world, as well as the story in some cases. The entire concept is linked with the story, and just feels really well connected.

31037503.review:
When I got this game, I did not know what to expect. Maybe I did expect to play a game where I would have to type, but I did not think I would be this engaged in the story.

First of all, I love the art style. It is absolutely stunning and even the parts that had less things placed around were a wonder to look at. The soundtrack is amazing and very calming and it is even right when you go into battle, it just gets your attention more.

The story is a bit all over the place if you do not stick to something, but that is very hard to do. All the bits collected from the different parts of the world come and mold together into an outstanding story about a female character. The narration is beautifully done and the voice acting is good. What I liked more about it is that even when you hurried through areas and you pass 2 or 3 places where the narrator starts talking, if she is saying the words from the first part, she will not just cut in the middle of the text and jump to the next one. The narration is continued normally and it flows so naturally.

The game is not really for everybody, but it is a nice adventure with somewhat challenging experiences and is very pleasant to look at. If you have any intention to buy this game, as small as it is, just buy it. It will be worth your time and money.

Unlike other typing games, Epistory doesn’t sacrifice its game play in order to be an ‘education game’ but instead weaves both together to create something really unique. The art style is lovely, a blend of origami and animation styles that I haven’t seen before. As for story, its good, better than I expected from a game like this but it’s overall ending lacked some of the emotional impact I was hoping for. Overall the game is worth your time, especially if you’re looking for something you haven’t seen before.

30985487.review:
[b]Epistory - Typing Chronicles [/b] - редкий алмаз в мире инди-игр. Основная особенность - решение задачек, украшение мира и убийство врагов - посредством печатанья на клавиатуре слов. Чем быстрее печатаешь - тем больше набираешь очков и прокачиваешь персонажа. Согласитесь, редко можно увидеть игру, которую можно пройти только на клавиатуре за счет написания слов. Как минимум за оригинальность уже можно купить ее. Другой положительной чертой, о которой говорили в обзорах не так много - адаптивная сложность. Насколько же это удачно, не нужно задумываться о выборе сложности, лишь ваше мастерство печатания определит сложность. Отсюда вытекает сложность игры - ее может пройти любой и каждому игра не покажется слишком сложной или слишком простой. Как это не удивительно, что для компьютерного новичка с 15 словами в минуту, что профессиональному "клавиатурщику" с 120 словами игра понравится.

В последнее время, когда инди-игры уже раза в 5 обогнали по количеству в стиме крупнобюджетные проекты, очень сложно найти что-то выдающиеся. В этот раз повезло.

30874561.review:
[h1]Epistory: Typing Chronicles[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Epistory: Typing Chronicles is one of the most simple yet unique games I have played in quite a while. It puts you in the boots of the muse of a struggling writer, a little girl riding on a fox who has to travel around in an origami world and return the world to its former glory.

The story is surprisingly upbeat and usually starts off with the little girl going into a gloomy world which seems to close around her and her overcoming all odds to come out of the world at the end of each act. The story is told through a narrator with the words appearing on the map itself as the story is being told. There is something so nice and sweet about the story that made me want to progress through it to see what new things the game threw at me.

The gameplay of Epistory revolves around your typing. You move around with WASD or a different combination of keys given by the game to maintain your hand in a good position for typing. You need to switch between movement and typing by a single tap of the space key and then proceed to type the words out given on the screen.

 Obstacles like wood and fire pits can be removed from the way by typing. The enemies that come towards you can only defeated by typing. Small enemies require less words to type with some even requiring a single letter while larger enemies can require up to 8 words and big ones at those. As you string together combos and defeat enemies, you get more XP and points. You can use your XP to unlock various perks which help give special abilities like knockback and fire spells to your word attacks or simple ones which increase the intensity of your attacks.

 These points are used to unlock new areas which in turn help in progressing through the story. There are a few puzzles through in there for good measure which are simple and require trial and error. The gameplay is simple and effective and the game has a dynamic difficulty setting which changes the difficulty based on your typing speed. There are certain chests scattered around the world which contains bonus or artifacts which also require typing to unlock. 

The game does have some confusing parts regarding exploration and you might get stuck after completing certain parts. The game world features a hub called The bridge which has portals which go to different new areas.  The game does not require a mouse and can be played entirely with a keyboard and even navigating through the menu is quite easy due to this. 

Epistory can get brutally difficult at times due to the simple reason that enemies can kill you with a single hit if they reach you and sometimes you will miss out seeing an enemy and that will lead to your demise. But the game starts you off back just where you died except in wave battles at the end of any area. Overall, Epistory holds true for the fact that simple gameplay can also lead to effective experiences.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

Epistory features an origami world which changes as the story goes on and unfolds before you like a page turner. There is a certain charm in the world that immediately draws you in the game and never lets go. The environments while nothing new, are really well done and have a lot of variety in them. The only problem here is the way the enemies look in the world when the camera zooms out. It becomes quite difficult to pinpoint small enemies and can result in some cheap deaths. 

[h1]Sound[/h1]

The sound design of Epistory is absolutely fantastic. The game has a stellar soundtrack which goes hand to hand with the overall nature of the game and it has a soothing touch to it. The voice acting and sound effects are also done very well and overall Epistory has a complete sound package you would want from a game like this.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Epistory is one of the few surprising games I have played recently and I absolutely adored it. The game has an incredible feel to it and I am just glad that I got to review this game because it might have easily been gone into my pile of backlogs if I didn’t have to review it. The game is stellar at its price point and a steal if you find it on a sale. You should definitely check Epistory out for its charming nature and stellar world building. 

[h1]Rating: 90/100[/h1]


This review was brought to you by [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/SilasReviews]Silas Reviews[/url]. For more reviews like this, please give the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/SilasReviews#curation]Curator[/url] a follow.

30803322.review:
[b]Epistory is just like Diablo, except...[/b]

-Instead of frantically clicking your mouse when monsters start shambling or skittering your direction, you frantically type words that appear above them.  This is a lot more fun/stressful than it sounds.

-Your character rides a red fox.  Also, the fox has three tails for some reason.

-Instead of dark macabre surroundings, everything here is word/writing-related. The background story reveals itself on the very ground you walk on and new areas to explore unfold like origami.  A pretty and consistent theme.

-You don’t use a mouse.  Or a controller.  Or a joystick.  Or a VR headset.  Or a trackball.  Or a Pong paddle dimmerswitch thingie (what were those called?).  You just use your keyboard.  If you hate typing and don’t ever want to do it or improve then you should probably move on, this game will make you cry.  But who am I to tell you what to do?  Maybe you need a good cry. Whatever you need man.

-Ironically, the loot you find in Epistory consists of paintings that flesh out the storyline, unlike Diablo loot that drops in piles of multicolored words.

-You learn vocabulary, which probably isn’t that surprising since you spend a good portion of time typing in multiple synonyms of things you encounter.  Even the game’s name encourages you to look something up in the dictionary… [I]Epistory, now that is an unusual name, sounds like some other word…Epistemolgy?  Epitaph?  Epistolary, that’s the one.  What does that mean again?  “relating to the writing of letters.”[/I]  Ahh, I see what you did there typing game.  Well played.

-Instead of the obvious goal in Diablo (kill Diablo), here it is much more subtle.  A story is revealed in parts as you explore.  I think you are trying to.… solve a mystery? inspire an author? create a narrative?  I’m not really positive yet.  Like I said, more subtle.

On second thought, I guess the game isn't that much like Diablo.  It is pretty good though.  I had completely forgotten that typing games existed until this one popped up on sale on Steam.  It, somewhat surprisingly, teaches you a skill, and makes you want to get better at it.  Since, in order to get good at most games, you have to practice a bunch of arbitrary keystrokes and mouse clicks, you might as well make one that hones a skill that is helpful outside the game.
  
So thumbs up Epistory.  You taught me something.

30765902.review:
移動はよくあるWASD等でできるし、わからなければ十字でもできる。
最初からチュートリアルで始まるので特に難しいと悩む点はない、詰まったのならオプションから難易度を下げるなりして対応すべし。
また、ストーリーもさることながらアリーナモードが素晴らしい。本編中でも度々出てくる敵をひたすらに撃退していくモードがひたすらに楽しめる。属性を変える、倒す敵の優先度を考える等なかなか奥が深いし楽しい。

　文字の入力に制限があるのは他の人も言うとおり。それもひとつのシステムとして割り切ってしまうとまた楽しめるのでそこまで苦ではない（慣れるのは良くないけど）。
ここからはダメなところ。「XXXXX」という文字がなぜか入力できない（自分だけかも）のでこいつが出てきた瞬間にゲームが終わってしまう。これはアリーナだけでなくストーリーでも言えることだが。翻訳が微妙だったり漢字のまま横文字の言葉をタイプするのはどうなんだろうって思ったりもする。

とりあえず体験版も有るので一回それをやってみよう。どうしても合わないとか世界観が無理ともならない限りオススメができる。タイピングが早くなるとパソコンを触るのがより一層楽しくなる。


追記　7時間ほどかけてとりあえずストーリーモードクリアしました。PCが悪いのかゲームが悪いのかラスト手前あたりに20分近いラッシュがぶっこまれてきてホントイライラしました。誤字、出てきたら詰む敵、敵の出る間隔が10秒位空いたりして完全に作業ゲーになったりしました。タイピングが好きというよりかはこのゲームに対しての愛だけが僕を突き動かしていました。改善待ってます。

追記2：Twitterにて翻訳担当の方からリプライを頂いたところ誤字や脱字の更新はすでにしているがなぜかEpistoryの公式がアップーデートをしてくれないとのことです。公式いい加減にしろ！

If you do know how to type this game will be much easier. If your learning how to type it should be no problem. Its  a i3 5005U 8gigs of ram just using the intergrated graphics card. Frame rate is around 30 to 40frames per second. So not high. Setting was at fast. 

My desktop I get a steady 60 fps at beautiful. Its a i5 with a 750ti. Its also a lot easier to type using my desktop keyboard  as that keyboard is a lot better. So this plays like a action RPG with stats you can raise. No weapons although your character does use Fire to hit a enemy. It does have dungeons. It does have chests. 30697549.review:
This would be my first typing game on Steam I've ever played. I picked it up because I've been wanting to try this sort of game for a while to see if I could improve my typing ability and, obviously, because it's friggin' gorgeous! Oh and fox mount, yeah! Oh, oh... oh, AND it was on sale! :D So I though, why not?

The default setting for this game is set as "adaptive difficulty," I believe, which I hadn't realized until things got unbearable. I was "blazing" through Chapter 1. After like, the 2nd to last "boss battle"-thing, I was dreading the next. Haha, I got slaughtered! "No, game! I'm not as good as you THINK I am!" lol (Now playing on a SET difficulty, thank you very much.) 

SO, yeah, in the "boss battles" (cuz I'm not sure what else to call them) enemies start to swarm you left and right, and you have to destroy them before they reach your circle. When they do, it's instadeath. The strategy is pretty simple but it's the execution that determines winning or losing. The longer the battle goes on, the faster they spawn and the harder prioritizing targets become. It starts to get pretty overwhelming, especially when your fingers decide they no longer wish to participate and type words/letters that have nothing to do with any word on the screen!!! *sobs*

Another thing I really like, is that this game has introduced several words I have never seen nor heard used before, like "riebeckite," "speleothem," "goyazite..." all some sort of cave rock formations and some others that I can't recall because it all happened so quick!! But, I like seeing new words!

Hopefully, with my new SET difficulty, I'll be able to actually focus on improving my typing "skizzels" while having a blast in this beautiful world. I can't wait to play more when I get the chance. Definitely recommend this game for anyone even remotely interested.

W szkole podstawowej, na lekcjach informatyki, mieliśmy zajęcia z szybkiego pisania na klawiaturze. Używaliśmy Mistrza Klawiatury. Programu, który wypluwał losowe słowa i sprawdzał szybkość, poprawność i rytmikę pisania. Poza tym był po prostu mozolny, nudny i brzydki. Pogratuluję szkole, która do podobnych zajęć kupiłaby chociaż na jedno stanowisko tę grę. 

Epistory - Typing Chronicle jest grą po prostu ładną. 
Wykorzystuje nieszablonowy mechanizm wypisywania pojawiających się na ekranie słów, aby pchnąć do przodu fabułę. Fabułę, która swoją drogą jest przemyślana, zaciekawia gracza, a na końcu nawet zaskakuje. Całość okraszona jest przepiękną grafiką stylizowaną na figurach origami. Momenty, w których nowe fragmenty mapy rozwijają się niczym arkusze papieru były dla mnie najprzyjemniejszymi. Do tego przyjemna muzyka w tle. Znośny system rozwoju postaci a przede wszystkim zmienny poziom trudności. W końcowych etapach gry sam musiałem się dobrze napocić, żeby zdążyć z wypisaniem wszystkich słów poprawnie, zanim przeciwnik mnie dopadł. 

Z ręką na sercu polecam!

[i]Gdy wpadam w szał
Wyrywam własne kartki
Zbierasz je i składasz z nich
Żurawie origami[/i]

29726208.review:
While there are some programs and games dedicated to polishing typing ability, only a handful of them can be described as both entertaining and good. Typing practice is not exactly associated with excitement; which is probably why the topic is mostly avoided.

However, Epistory creators managed to combine the core idea of typing with beauty and fun.

Everything in this game revolves around words, texts and typing. The menu can be navigated by typing commands, the abilities are switched by typing their names. The enemies are fended off with the power of typing as well. Every time the narrator reads out another bit of the enigmatic story, the text appears on the ground, where it stays at least until the end of the chapter. Also, the land is formed out of what looks like sheets of paper filled with writing. Every time the player unlocks a new patch of land, the world unfolds beautifully, like a cross between pop-up books and origami figurines. While the graphic style might seem simplistic, it goes very well with the aesthetic of a world of paper.

As for how typing works in battles, I personally find it very well implemented. One might complain that the set up looks hardly exciting - the main character typically stands in a stone circle during longer battles and the enemies approach her - but this is not the case. Once one of the beasts comes too close, the girl and her companion fox are killed and the entire fight sequence has to be repeated. Additionally, enemy types are varied not only in terms of size and speed but also the number of words assigned to them (think of them as their "health") and their difficulty.
The player collects four elemental abilities throughout the game, each one having a different debilitating effect on adversaries (fire burns additional word, ice freezes enemies in place, lightning jumps between them and wind gusts push them back), but once the player learns new skills... monsters immune to all skills but one corresponding to their colour start to appear. This makes the combat a bit nerve-wracking at times - the enemies approach slowly but steadily, getting closer and closer while the player tries to make no mistakes.
Personally I think that my experience with Epistory helped me improve the way I type. Although, I have never loathed and feared my mother tongue more than I did when I saw monsters adorned with words like "gżegżółka" and "pięćdziesięciogroszówka". Playing Epistory in Polish is not for the faint of heart.

Apart from fighting enemies and unearthing lost treasures, the player has to face some environmental puzzles as well. Sadly, this is probably the least satisfying element of the game. The puzzles are on the easy side to the point they can be considered a bit boring. There really isn't much to talk about - some ice physics, pressing switches here and there, finding a code and pressing some more switches in the right order.

TL;DR Epistory is a great experience, with beautiful visuals and a cool idea. Also, playing it can actually improve your typing skill. Beware the Polish language in this game.

29672128.review:
[h1]EYE CANDY, EYE CANDY[/h1]

Eu preciso de poucas razões para começar a jogar qualquer jogo, mas de fato, os games com visual diferenciado sempre estão no topo da minha lista de prioridades. O Epistory – Typing Chronicles me ganhou exatamente nesse quesito, mas depois de algum tempo de jogo acredito que ele tem muitas qualidades que merecem ser pontuadas.

Pensei: [i]“Vou digitar as palavras para a personagem andar e nada muito além disso.” [/i] Pois então, fui surpreendida ao ver que esse conceito foi incorporado de forma bastante consistente e dinâmica no jogo inteiro, desde o menu – onde o/a jogador/a escolhe as opções digitando o nome das mesmas –, passando pelos upgrades da personagem, interação com objetos do cenário e combate.

Ao invés de cansativo e repetitivo, me diverti muito com a exploração do cenário e com as lutas – especialmente com a forma como poderes elementais foram agregados à mecânica de combate – e percebi que não havia sentido o tempo passar. 

O [b]ponto negativo[/b], para mim, foi a história principal: ela acabou ficando em segundo plano. Juro que estou quase no final do jogo e nem sei qual é a história direito. Acho que é muita informação de uma vez só vez: leitura, audição, digitação.. meus reflexos não dão conta.

Mas, acho que super vale a pena conhecer o jogo!
[b] Recomendo! [/b]

29424492.review:
I just finished this literally within the last minute.

I'm in love with it. It's so charming and full of genuine feeling in its story and how the game communicates to you through gameplay...which is also addicting. I had trouble putting this game down, even when I was getting too tired to type or be sharp-witted enough to handle a horde of enemies. 

It's a calm, peaceful game with a low, glowing hum of positive feeling throughout, without being too thick on emotion in any way. The voice acting on the part of the narrator/main character is very effective; you feel her vulnerability and painful determination to not fail in equal measure. 

The art direction is fantastic with a beautiful palette for the game, and the paper world is lovely. I've seen sometimes where there's a twist to the world, like it's made of paper or something similar...and blessedly, this game doesn't try to shove at you LOOK AT HOW CLEVER WE ARE about the paper world. It just...is. That's a wonderful thing.

Exploring is incredibly rewarding, and the game has excellent AI that detects your own ability and adjusts accordingly. 'Combat' even becomes very strategic later in the game, since the AI knows your difficulty well by now and you must figure out very quickly how to manage the swarm descending upon you.

I love this game. I can't wait to play it for my channel, and to try to share it with others. I'll probably check out other games by the developer as well!

29406261.review:
This is a game that's hard to review under Steam's binary system. I like the game well enough, but t has frustrating elements and the non-typing aspects, which is why I bought this game instead of playing Typing of the Dead, are minimal and don't carry the gameplay outside of keyboard-mashing. Epistory is a fun typing tutor, but that's pretty much all it is. I've seen it billed as a mashup of typing tutors and RPGs like Bastion, but it's not as deep as games in that genre can be. There are some puzzles along the way that are a bit tricky, and the art is well done and interesting, but those elements on its own are pretty weak. If you are looking for a typing game, this one does the trick, but don't expect it to be any deeper than that. Full disclosure, I am 30+ years old and lifelong gamer, so my expectations may be a bit high. It could be that if you are buying this game for a child, they will find it utterly delightful.

First, the typing. The game is pretty good there. It's easy to control the game and explore the world while keeping your hands on home row. You move around with either WASD or an alternative control that uses F and J, the "anchor keys" of home row and I and E, which is the key your middle fingers hit on the row above. It's quite comfortable to navigate the isometric game world that way. I do wish I could rebind the keys, though. I think shifting the WASD setup over to the right a bit would also work well for movement while keeping my hands on home row. 

When an enemy or destructible barrier shows up, you shift into combat mode by pressing space, and start typing away. To reach the menu, you hit Tab. One of my favorite details is that you can navigate the menu by typing. You want to open the upgrade screen, you can type "upgrade." It's a nice touch that keeps the flow of the typing going.

Combat is okay. Again, at its core, it's a typing game and there's only so much you can do to spice that up. Enemies approach you from all directions, and you hurt them and knock them back by typing the words that appear above them. Most combat happens at fixed points, and you are frozen in place while the enemies come at you. If a single enemy gets close enough to touch you, it's game over. You will unlock elemental powers along the way that have different effects. Ice will freeze them, fire will damage them over time and burn the next word over time, etc. You switch powers by typing "Ice" or "fire." It works well and doesn't break flow, but sometimes I did accidentally switch to ice while typing something else. 

Towards the end of the game (hopefully), the combat just becomes a slog. Since all you do is type at enemies, the only thing the game can do to make it challenging is to throw more enemies at you. These encounters can become tedious, especially since you have a single hit point, and battles can last for several minutes. One particular maddening fight, which prompted me to write ths review, had me struggling for a long time. I was in a dark cave, and I had to constantly attack crystals to keep the lights on. If the crystal went out, I couldn't see the words above the enemies and couldn't fight them. I died four times before I gave up and turned on the "adaptive difficulty." I couldn't manually go to a lower setting, I had to die a couple times before the game knocked me down to an easy enough fight that I could finish. As bad as that was, it was the next fight that really bothered me. It was a normal fight, enemies came at me and I could see them right away. The lowered difficulty manifested itself by slower and fewer enemies. I rarely had more than 2 enemies on the screen at a time, but the fight still dragged on forever, all the while my dog was whimpering to go outside because you can't pause the game mid-battle for some reason. I beat that fight without really feeling challenged, let my dog out, anf when I saw the next fight coming, I just had to quit. I couldn't stand the thought of another five-minute slog.

Outside combat, there's exploration, hard-to-find chests, backtracking as your new elemental powers open new areas, unlockable artwork which fills in some backstory, and some puzzles here and there. All of that is fairly bland and unchallenging. You have buttons you have to walk across in sequence, patches of ice where you can't change direction until you hit a wall, and other puzzles that I've seen in several other games. Nothing particularly stood out as being very fun or challenging, but again as an adult I may be expecting more variety than most people looking to play a typing game. Your reward for most of this is experience, which you can use to buy upgrades. There's nothing game-changing about the upgrades, nor is there much of a choice about what to upgrade. Right now, I have enough experience to have everything upgraded

The story is pretty vague, your character's identity is only "the Muse," and so far I haven't really found any answers. Each dungeon has 4 or 5 chests with a piece of a picture. Each one adds an element to that dungeon's picture. Collect them all and you will see a picture of (presumably) the main character's life on the planet earth. But there's still no mention of how or why she got to this book-themed world. It's probably going to end up as some sort of allegory, one dungeon had some definite colegiate overtones, but there's not enough there to relly entice me.

I don't know if I'm going to pick this game up again. If I do, it won't be for the story, the puzzles, or the art. It'll just be to sharpen my typing skills. Maybe it was foolish for me to expect more from a typing game. Just don't go in expecting the same, either.

29115337.review:
Pros:

+ The art is gorgeous. Coupled with the soundtrack, it provides a relaxing experience

+ Puzzle elements included (although they are relatively easy)

+ Encourages exploration

+ Each dungeon is unique from each other

+ Each of the 4 elements (water, fire, wind, spark) have their advantages and disadvantages. The player can also switch the elements at any point.

+ Unique way to tell the story

+ The difficulty scales evenly (with adaptive difficulty turned on)

+ Arena mode enables the player to improve their typing skills

Cons:

- Sometimes the words can be blocked by the environment. For example, when playing in the labriynth arena, the words can be blocked by the trees. I feel that for a typing game, the words should always be visible, since reaction time is critical.

- When clearing the corrupted nests, the narration should be paused, as the player would be too focused on the enemies to pay any attention to the story.

- The story is rather short as it can be finished in 5 hours.

Verdict: 8/10

Conclusion: 

Its mechanics and art are amazing and you don't even have to be good at typing to enjoy this game. This game would definitely be a good break from other hardcore games.

Skvělá hra.
A jak přidali češtinu, tak bych možná řekl, že pro mnohé i krapet těžší? 
O co jde? Sám nevím, ale je to pěkný ten příběh, zatím jej po hodině a něco moc nechápu, neboť hádám, že se skládá z útržků vyprávění, které se odvíjí dle toho, jakou hlavní část příběhu jste si vybrali dobrovolně teď splnit. 
A to tak, že píšete slova, čímž obnovujete les, který pak zarůstá kytičkami a houbami, uvolňujete si cestu vpřed zapálením strní a bráníte se před hmyzem. 
A na ty útoky pak navazuje magie, jako led, či oheň, která se dá v průběhu souboje střídat a každý z nich dělá něco jiného.

A na to jsou zde různé vychytávky, třeba si odemknete za zkušenostní body odsunutí nepřátel po každém vašem slově, či rychlejší pálení slov po ohnivé magii.

28855164.review:
Fun in some ways, but there are enough flaws here that it's really not worth your time.

I was not able to pay any attention to the story during frantic typing sections, so I can't comment on the story much. It seems throwaway, though, trying to be thoughtful and provokative but really just lots of empty words to fill the space and show a specific kind of style.

The world map layout is confusing and it took me a lot of backtracking and random wandering around to be able to figure out where to go. I stumbled onto chapter 4 before chapter 3, because that's actually possible, but I couldn't progress because I hadn't unlocked the right type of magic.

When adaptive difficulty is on, the game actually gets to be too hard too fast. No amount of strategy is going to save you from the absolutely overwhelming swarm of words you have to type if you're a good typist to begin with. I had to turn adaptive difficulty off to stand a chance, at which point the game was still frantic enough to be fun...

...until I got to the wind dungeon. There's a section here where it zooms out (so everything is small), and there are both birds and wasps (the birds are harmless, the wasps aren't, and they're small enough that you can't really tell them apart), and the wasps only have 1 letter to type each (making them difficult to spot sometimes), and the background is really bright (making it hard to tell the letters apart from the background). What a completely awful encounter design. It's like it's hand-crafted to frustrate, and after quite a bit of interesting and thoughtful encounter design it was just a complete experience-killing 180.

Don't waste your time. If you're just in it for some fast typing practice, there are plenty of free websites out there.
