There's even "Arena Mode" in which you can go on forever and try to better your score.  You can see world-wide stats, as well as stats from your friends.  I highly recommend this game, as it hones one's typing skills while also playing a fun game.

28850945.review:
[Updated Review] 
   ^ Rewriting this review actually makes me want to replay the game again soon.

=== Pros ===

- Wow. It's a typing game! 

I used to play old school typing games from the 90's as a kid, so I found this a nostalgic, yet very refreshing and engaging take on the genre.

- Lovely, soothing narration
- Great adaptation of a less mainstream genre, ie. typing games.
- Pretty unique artstyle and animation that stands out by itself.
- ^ Stands out, AND suits the game's concept amazingly well. (Paper, writing or typing, unfolding a story, uncovering ...areas)
- Satisfying to "level up" 
- Achievements were satisfying
- Riding on the back of a fox vaguely reminds me of riding on the back of the wolf (sort of) in Okami, another nostalgic game
- It's great being able to freely explore a lovely world in a typing game for a change.
- I do like foxes :p


=== Little details I appreciate: ===

- When selecting an option at the main menu and such, you can type the letters of what you want to select rather than just clicking.
- There are several different ways to control the characters. You can use the recommended EF and IJ, or WASD, or another set of keys. I used the recommended EF/IJ setting.


=== Cons (?) ===
#1.
I'm really nitpicking here. Whether this point is a plus or minus for you would depend on your own personal typing skills in general, or how relaxing you want this experience to be.

At chapter 1, there was already a lot of frantic typing. I was worried it would eventually become so difficult that it would be unplayable later on, but I was wrong. The tough part for me was at the beginning when I needed to get used to the game, the different "elements" (you'll see what I mean when you unlock more areas), and just having to warm up my fingers. 

In fact, towards the end of the last chapter I found it wasn't challenging or fresh enough for me. I was disappointed, but I think that was more of my own fault. I tend to get carried away playing and start anticipating crazy boss fights that I can win to feel smug about. 

Still, I think this level of difficulty might be just right for others. It definitely doesn't make it unplayable for people who haven't grown up with stressful typing games like The Typing Of The Dead. Plus, there's always the difficulty settings to tweak.

...

#2.
Nitpicking again. I felt the ending was a teeeeny bit on the simple side. 

Actually, I don't know if this can be considered a bad thing. The only reason I felt the ending was too simple was the fact that the narration and build up was so fantastic. It made me think and wonder about what was going on story-wise as I typed and typed frantically throughout the game.

It probably works for some people who want simple stories. Also, if I recall correctly (finished it a year earlier), the ending might have had a bit of an open-ended aspect so you could probably imagine your own backstory or interpretation in addition to the simple one. And I appreciate stuff like that. I like it when my thoughts linger on a game or story even when I'm not playing. :D


=== Glitches ===

- I don't recall anything specifically game-breaking?
- I might have had like...two (?) problematic instances, but it was easily solved by relaunching the game. I don't remember what the problems were exactly because they didn't happen enough for me to take note of.


=== Summary ===
- It's a well-made game.
- I really enjoyed this. 
- I'd recommend this.
    ^ (unless you hate typing)

28768292.review:
One of those games that popped out of my steam library under the "Typing" tag. That is curious, because there aren't so much typing games here on Steam. Fired up the game and something caught my attention: eveything is a piece of paper, from the protagonist to the world around her. A nice, soft touch that this game embraced completely, and helped to define its identity since the first minute of gameplay. You will be confused about the plot at the beginning, but it isn't the core of the experience. You are asked to travel places and fight monsters only using your keyboard. No mouse, no frenetic button smashing, there's only you accompanied with a narrator and the words printed directly on the level. 
The core mechanic is to fight your foes standing on the ground and type the words above them as quickly as possible in order to defeat them. If you're typing faster enough the game will reward you with lots of experience points that you can use for upgrading your skills and abilities. You'll be getting more powers throughout the game as unlockables, and those are selectable just by typing them. 
These simple mechanics united with a peculiar art style makes a perfect "break game" when you just need to sit and relax, enjoying the journey. 
Yes, it's definitely a journey, and one of the best in my opinion.
The only thing that I did not like personally was the ending, but it's not important. The gameplay is perfectly refined to make it very enjoyable.
Sure, it isn't perfect, has its flaws (a bit repetitive maybe and a few minor bugs), but the price it's worth the ticket. And in these days there aren't so many games that can rely on that.

28724870.review:
To be honest, I have no idea what I just played, but I remember enjoying it quite a bit. Epistory TC is a typing game as you may have guessed from the title. You play a fox and girl combination. The fox walks, the girl casts spells, by typing (as you may have guessed). Areas are blocked off until you collect the appropriate magic to clear them. The game concludes after collecting all of the magic and going to the Lost Desert (and winning the boss battle there). Since you need all four magics to get there, I assume that's always the ending location. On top of that, the credits rolled after it, so... yeah.

The narrator's voice is really well done. Shoutout to you, Rachael. I don't remember your last name, but know that I read the credits just to know your name to give you props. It's really compelling. The art is stylistically consistent, and good. Everything looks like it's some origami nightmare. I'm not sure about what the story is about though. Or even if there is a consistent story. If anything, it might just be some kind of exploration narrative. You don't need a linking story because the player is the linker. I would be a little more satisfied if things made more sense. Like the ending looks like it was designed to be touching, but the effect is lost on me because I didn't know the prevailing story. The soundtrack to this game is quite nice, but not worth purchasing with the game if you ask me. 

Looking at that title image, I think there may be a visual glitch with the fox's tails. The fox in the game has three tails, that image looks like it has one. 

I won't complain about anything in the game, because it was a delight. However, I will say that the game is too easy. You're not penalized for misspelling a word in any way except that it'll take you more time to get to the next word. Some of the words they send your way I'm not even sure are words. Like there's this one that HAS to come from chemistry or something because it ends in vitriolic but the rest of the letters are like... what? No way. It has like 50 letters and is a pain to attempt to type. I usually cheat my way around it on boss fights. 

Anyway, as you can probably guess, I do recommend this game.

28724545.review:

28675797.review:
The good:
Epistory was my first experience with typing games, and a lovely one at that. I type quickly, so I played the adaptive difficulty and had just enough challenge to keep me interested in the well-paced typing adventure. Eventually your character learns new magic types, making battles more dynamic. Your typing destroys enemies - woodland insects and arachnids - as well as terrain, opening up new areas to explore and chests to open. The typing mechanic never feels forced; the game is linguistic through and through. Each word typed feels organic and relevant to the unfolding story. There's much to explore (even more than is necessary for the storyline), and the quaint yet geometric art style encourages you to do so. The story itself is beautiful and unassuming; Epistory is unexpectedly touching. (And don't worry, you are still free to explore the world even after the story's final chapter.)

The bad:
As much as I treasure this indie gem, I had a few issues. Some of the ice puzzles were nothing but tedious and incredibly difficult to complete - not because they were difficult to solve, but because the design was antagonistic. The game has an arena option, where you can put your typing skills to the test and compete on the leaderboards. It's a fun game mode for nerds like me who enjoy typing, but it's buggy in fullscreen. Speaking of typing nerds - I type over 100 wpm, which is (at times) faster than the game could register - problematic during some battles.

The end:
Epistory is surprising. It's charming, it's unique, it's enjoyable. It's one of those games you play on a bit of a whim, and then you come to revel in your discovery of. Epistory is one of those lovely games none of your friends know about... until you tell them... and you will.

28350228.review:
So my typing courses have proven their usefulness in many serious situations. I did not have to waste time during my many university courses that required ridiculously long answers and in my current job I get to write out my notes while still on the line with my customers. But with Epistory I got to explore a beautiful world and honed my skills in split-second decision-making. 

THE GOOD
Beautiful graphics with a unique look to them.
Clear and straightforward set of challenges with a steady learning curve.
Plenty of challenges that require the full set of skills.

THE (subjectively) GOOD
I just love the main gameplay mechanic and it allowed me to hone a skill that I was already quite good at (10-fingers blind typing for over a decade)

THE BAD
I did not care much for the story, it hinted at trauma, loss, personal development and an overarching mystery of why this little girl is running around a paperfolded world on a fox. It did not dare to explore any of these themes in detail. If this was based on someone's personal experience, I did not get the feeling this was very genuine. 

why THE BAD shouldn't stop you from buying this game:
You can completely ignore the story, it is of no consequence to your overall enjoyment.

why THE GOOD should stop you from buying this game:
if you're dyslexic, can't type well or are bad at responding to challenges within a split-second, you should give this game a pass. You're required to be a typing speedster and can't afford to waste time finding the right letters on your keyboard. Go look over the shoulder of a typist as they absolutely ace the game instead. ;)

28336188.review: Fun for first few hours then it becomes way too repetitive and irritating. Plus the last arena thing you have to do is completely retarded, awful game design there.

28332860.review:
The gameplay for this game is really simple. You see an enemy, it has got a (or several) word above its head, you type the word and the enemy goes away. As simple as that... initially. But once there's 20 enemies coming at you in rapid succession, that's when it gets a little more tricky, mainly when the words ramp up in difficulty as well. And to make it somewhat more difficult, you have four different spells which you need to type the word of - spark, fire, ice and wind - in order to activate them. Certain spells for certain enemies every now and then.

Furthermore, the graphics are gorgeous. Whenever you reveal a new part of the land, it looks like as if it's made out of pages from a book. In fact, everything in this game looks like that and I loved it, it's like origami. The soundtrack is relaxing and fits the game perfectly, the narrator has got the perfect (smooth) voice for the story and yeah... it's awesome.

Finally, the story... and how fun is it as a whole? The story revolves around this girl who's riding on a three-tailed fox and it follows the writing process of a writer, who's trying to complete her story. The narration is the writers thoughts as it all unfolds in front of you. And yeah, it's really freaking fun, at least if you like to type and you like adventures games.

If you find it on a sale, there's no doubt that you need to buy it. Otherwise, follow my advice (see above).

28164407.review:
[h1]Хорошая игра. Перепроходить я её, конечно, не буду.[/h1]

В Стиме вообще очень мало игр стоимостью 799 рублей, не обладающих должным уровнем реиграбельности. Но беда ебистории в том, что вместе с тем она не содержит в себе ничего выдающегося. Это полнейший провал с точки зрения окупаемости.

Всё изначально находится на своих местах: отличные анимации и визуальные эффекты, интересная боевая система, нарратив, испытания для игрока, даже какая-то невнятная мораль есть. И все эти элементы находятся в строгих границах выдержанного диапазона "на среднем уровне". Хвалить игру только за интересную механику боя — недооценивать разнообразие игровой продукции на рынке.

Нет, механика боя в ней действительно занятная. Вот так выглядят все приколы локального геймплея с точки зрения кейлоггера:

«standrotrowpabeatnabicebarkshowfireblastcrowdfoe
brutepolkaslakematebragdragboomalsotakeaxeragfeesparkold
makewithicedigsfireweblineawedigssparkpurcelaneashsob
oldsinblockadedtaxiodermicdissertate»
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=811392234
Локация под названием Creation City нравится мне в этом плане больше остальных.

Но игра не отбивает запрашиваемую цену. Приобретая продукт, пользователь платит за эмоции, которые рассчитывает пережить за эти деньги. То, что предлагает игроку Эпистори, стóит, в лучшем случае, рублей двести.

И дело даже не в том, что игрок теряет "условие победы" спустя двадцать минут после запуска.
Дело не в том, что во время энкаунтеров здесь звучит однообразная боевая тема [а каждый энкаунтер ближе к концу игры растягивается на 5-7 минут, вот и посчитайте, кому понравится постоянно слушать один и тот же тревожный ксилофон].
В начале игры перед вами роняют фразу вроде «She found herself alone, lost in the dark». ВСЁ, с этого вы не сдвинетесь до конца повествования. С течением времени игра не меняется ни по уровню настроения, ни по уровню ясности. И дело даже не в том, что на отвлечённое нытьё главной героини очень быстро перестаёшь обращать внимание. 

Дело в том, что Эпистория — это яркий пример того, как игра не становится звёздочкой только за счёт каких-то необычных элементов геймплея. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=811393136
[h1]Оправдывает ли игра свою цену?[/h1]
Нет.
[h1]Интересно ли в это играть?[/h1]
Нет!
[h1]Стоит ли попробовать сыграть в это?[/h1]
Да, ради уникального игрового опыта.
[h1]Сопереживает ли игрок главному персонажу, проникается ли его историей?[/h1]
Нет. В этом плане Эпистория очень банальна. Нужно быть наивным, впечатлительным, либо эмоционально неопытным человеком, чтобы испытывать эмпатию к происходящему.
[h1]Есть ли в этой игре что-то по-настоящему необычное?[/h1]
Да.
Список ачивментов.
Нет, серьёзно, до этого ни одна игра не сравнивала мой прогресс с «Тёмной Башней» Стивена Кинга.

28147544.review:
Le point fort du jeu, c'est évidemment cette originalité de combattre les ennemis (des insectes, en général, me demandez pas pourquoi) en tapant des mots qui s'affichent au-dessus d'eux : des mots courts sur des ennemis lents au début, puis des mots plus longs (jusqu'à atteindre des mots hyper-techniques genre [i]désoxygénéisation[/i] !) avec des vagues d'ennemis de plus en plus nombreux et rapides.

La montée en difficulté est vraiment progressive et bien gérée, tout comme l'introduction de pouvoirs et de buffs reliés à différents éléments.

Le design est magnifique avec cet effet de papier plié, les couleurs sont châtoyantes (la plupart du temps, car j'ai moins aimé les niveaux souterrains ou intérieurs, forcément plus sombres), la musique apaisante (la plupart du temps puisque contre les boss, le tempo s'accélère pour nous mettre la pression).

Le scénario m'a paru globalement anecdotique même si le dénouement final est intéressant.

Quelques bugs ternissent parfois le tableau (ennemi bloqué ou apparaissant trop vite d'un coin de l'écran) mais ils sont vraiment rares.

Je le recommande donc fortement.

Jokes aside, I think the game's premise is brilliant: A writer (the Narrator), suffering from a massive writer's block, lets her character takes control of her own story. Because the Narrator is a writer, it makes perfect sense that typing takes center stage in the gameplay. 27956694.review:
[b]EPISTORY is a wonderful experience, well worth playing it. Interesting concept (typing game) followed by stunning origami-like visuals. Beautiful story unfolds nicely with time. Gameplay is enjoyable and does enough to keep you interested in playing until the end although controlling character might be a little tricky sometimes.[/b]

[b]STORY[/b]
Charming story with an interesting ending although it doesn't look like it at the beginning. The closer towards the end of the game the better clue of what's coming you have.

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]
In general gameplay is really fun. As it is a typing game all you need is your keyboard actually (imagine my surprise when I've accidentally found out that you can even control menu with typing). The controls might be a little clunky sometimes but once you get used to it it shouldn't be a big problem. There were 2 or 3 times when I had to replay nest-battle due to controls issue. Personally it wasn't much of a complaint for me but I can imagine that it might get somebody frustrated. One time game has crashed after I've beaten one of the levels and I had to complete it WHOLE once again. And of course it had to be the most boring level in Epistory...
Over time the game introduces new features and times it perfectly to keep you interested in playing:
- [i]languages[/i] which let you open new levels, territories and kill new enemies,
- skills related to [i]languages[/i] which you can upgrade to be more powerful,
- diffculty in battles (especially in nest-battles) where you have to switch between skills to beat different kind of enemies.
The only major minus of the game for me was nest-battles that have become a bit repetitive and boring at the end. Maybe the game's just adapted to my typing skills and lowered the difficulty of the battles, I don't know. It killed all the excitement though.

[b]VISUALS[/b]
The game is simply beautiful. Origami-like design gives so much charm I could stare at the surroundings for hours. There are a few levels of the game and all have their unique look and setting.

[b]SOUND[/b]
The music is pleasant, the dubbing was good although there's not much talking here - you will hear the narrator most of the times and occasionally inner thoughts of the character you control. Later in the game I had a few times an issue that nest-battle music didn't switch off after killing all the enemies.

27791440.review:
... I want to leave a good review but I can't.

I'm an adult who was looking to improve my occasionally-sloppy typing skills and figured I'd give this game a try.

The graphics are pretty good. I like the paper-origami style design of the world.

Music is okay but not great. It'll do.

The UI could definitely use improvement. Applying skill upgrades is clumsy. The menu system was definitely slapped on in a hurry.

The two places where the game lets me down is the story itself and then the combat/typing. The story is a bunch of meaningless word-salad with tween-drama dressing and a side of unnecessary feminism. Yea, I'm sorry. It doesn't even feel good saying that.... but it's true.

Combat isn't terrible, but I found that the game balance is a bit rough. Maybe it was the auto-balance system dealing with someone who is already a speed typist. I found the game was mostly too easy... until it became stupidly difficult and a failed a few trials. Some words are straight of the "Master Snobs Obscure Words Dictionary by Seattle Publishers LLC". fallaciloquence? vicambulate? Really. How about snobographer. Today I'm a snobographer.

I'd be good with learning new words if I actually knew what they meant instead of just hitting the right characters in order.

Bugs include certain words triggering fire/ice/spark usage instead of allowing the word to be completed, and sometimes words/letters are hard to see because they are out of focus or obscured by some object/effect on the screen.

Anyway, I was hoping for more out of this. Still, it's not horrible. Give it a try if you want to type.

Also check out http://zty.pe/ because pew pew lasers.

27491400.review:
Très beau et très bon jeu.

Bon quand j'ai vu ce jeu, j'étais septique mais aussi intrigué. Du coup, forcément je l'ai essayé.

Au départ, je me suis demandé si c'était un jeu ou un logiciel d'entrainement pour secrétaire mais force est de constater qu'après quelques minutes je me suis pris à l'histoire et le gameplay est rapidement passé de "étrange" à "cool".

L'histoire est assez sympa et est très bien rendue par la voie off et l'univers sonore du jeu. La fin est plutôt inattendue, ce qui est assez rare pour être sous-ligné.
Le jeu est relativement facile mais n'oublions pas que dans "relativement facile", il y a "relativement". Certains combats sont assez difficiles car la seule maitrise du clavier ne suffit plus et sans un minimum de stratégie, c'est l'échec assuré. Ne vous attendez donc pas à vous promener tranquillement pour profiter du décor tout le long du jeu.

Donc en résumé, c'est un petit jeu (mais pas si petit) sympa au gameplay original et à la narration très bien faite. Je recommande donc ce jeu à tout ceux qui aiment sortir des sentiers battus.

Et sinon au final, je suis devenu beaucoup plus efficace dans l'utilisation d'un clavier donc ce n'étais peut-être pas qu'un jeu...

27243024.review:
En quelques mots : Très rafraichissant visuellement et dépaysant d'un point de vue gameplay.

Je l'ai découvert peu après sa sortie mais n'avais pas sauté le pas, chose faite après avoir pu tester une démo avec les développeurs à la PGW 2016. 

La direction artistique est sublime (oui.. j'aime les origami, et alors?) et profite d'un level design qui réserve quelques surprises, l'adaptation de la difficulté à vos capacités à "taper" les mots rend le tout accessible aux plus lents (j'ai fait tester le jeu à des personnes non habituées à écrire au clavier qui s'en sont très bien sortis) et plus compliqué qu'il pourrait sembler pour les habitués (ayant expérimenté personnellement quelques sueurs froides et cris de victoire après avoir sur-estimer ma vitesse supra-luminique à assembler les syllabes! :b).

Ce n'est pas un produit que je recommanderais à tout les types de joueurs, mais certainement un jeu qui plaira aux personnes à la recherche d'une autre façon de jouer et qui sauront apprécier la poésie d'Epistory.

P.S.: Et puis, si jamais vous n'êtes que moyennement tentés mais que vous tombez dessus pendant les soldes, faites l'expérience! Vous ne pourrez pas être totalement déçus! ;)

26877914.review:
The main gameplay of epistory - typing chronicles is a type 'em up. This is not a game to learn how to type. It expects that you already know how to type correctly on a QWERTY keyboard. If that sounds like fun then this game is for you. 

The main character rides a fox and interacts with objects and different insect enemies by typing the words that appear over them. You press the spacebar to switch from moving to being able to attack enemies by typing. The game does a great job of showing you how to play and letting you experiment rather than hand holding tutorials. It tells you how to do the different controls once and that is it. Anything that is in the specific font type can be interacted with by typing. This includes all of the menus. 

The progression for the game is four different elemental types that can be applied to a typed word. For example fire, will light torches and burn through thick paper. When you successfully type a word against an enemy using fire then the next word slowly burns to more easily defeat the enemy.

The movement controls are slightly awkward at first but once you get past that it works really well. The story is pretty bland and doesn't grab or hold the player's attention. The gameplay, art and sound direction are what shines in this game. The game is also fairly short probably about 5 hours for 100 percent completion. I would recommend you pick up the game when it is on sale since it is a shorter game and not worth the full 20 dollar price. I got the game as part of one of the humble monthly bundles and was pleasently surprised with the quality of the game

Pros

The paper craft art style is beautiful.
Soundtrack fits the different locations very well.
Everything is in terms of paper throughout.
All menus and options can be selected through typing which means your hands never have to leave the keyboard.
The controls are interesting but take some adjustment.

Cons

Short 3-5 hours.
Story is fairly bland.
Words per minute is not displayed to the player.
No option to change the movement controls.

26717949.review:
[h1]I was expecting a simplistic "typing" game.  But this, [b]this[/b] was fantastic![/h1]

What an incredible way to tell a story!  The overall art style was amazing, the way written pages come to life to form the scenery and terrain and reveal new areas of the map -- brilliant!  Everything about the game seems to be very well done.

The game is a simple game of exploring and while doing so the story is revealed through both narration and text that appears on the terrain.  Along the way various obstacles and terrain objects (rocks, trees, etc) can either be removed or be revealed by typing the word associated with them.  And naturally attacks are performed by typing their respective words as well.

The monsters/bugs you encounter come in a variety of sizes and speeds.  Small little bugs can be killed with a single word, where larger bugs may take 3 words, and large bugs can even take more.  Generally the larger they are the more number of words it takes to finally kill them; and for bosses the words even get much longer words as well!

Attacks also take various forms as you progress through the game.  When in attack/typing-mode (entered by hitting SPACE or ENTER) you can type the words ICE or FIRE, for example, to change to your preferred attack method of the 4 ultimately available through the game.  ICE freezes the bugs for a few seconds, giving you additional time to continue typing their words before they continue their advance toward you.  FIRE starts burning the bug's next word, so you can continue fighting one of the many other advancing bugs on you, and after a few seconds that first bug's word is totally burned up and removed the same as if you typed it.

On each section of map that is revealed there is generally a "Nest".  When you stand on a Nest, you enter a mode where you can't move and a bunch of insects from all around you start advancing on you.  This continues for quite awhile and is quite challenging and stressful!  It's awesome and what a great feeling of accomplishment when you finally fend off that last giant bug which may take some enormous words to finally finish off!

Also, through exploration, you'll encounter simple puzzles too usually solved by standing on certain blocks in a certain order.  Exploration is also rewarded by placing chests around the map as well.  This is a good thing because as you get points, you can then buy upgrades to your skills and abilities -- longer duration ICE takes affect, faster run speed, etc.

The only downsides to me were that I missed (didn't hear/pay attention to) the story as I was either exploring or keeping too close an eye out for bugs, and the game by the end felt longer than it was and I was ready for it to end.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Fantastic art style and environment.
+ Nice exploration and rewards for doing so.
+ Challenging.  (The options say it adjusts for your typing ability.)
+ Polished.  Everything's very well done with full narration.
+ Great idea for different types of attacks.
+ Great selection of words.
+ Words often relate to the a theme or object

[h1]Cons:[/h1] [i](But these are minor)[/i]
- Sometimes I missed narration due to random fighting (or just my focus was elsewhere)
- Couldn't always tell where you needed to go to continue the story
- Felt a little long.  6.5 hrs for me for a pretty thorough play through.  (Though that could be a good thing in that there is a lot to offer.)

[h1]Overall:  This was a far better game than I could have imagined any typing game could be.  9 out of 10[/h1]

26572964.review:
It's pretty cozy, but pretty clunky as well. An awkwardly told story, and a relatively incidental protagonist (as far as the narrative goes), leave the game to stand on the merits of its typing tests. The attempts at puzzles (e.g. interweaved doors, stepping on panels in a sequential order) just sort of drag out the exploration gameplay between 'fight' scenes. The typing is fun enough: you combine up to four types of attacks against waves of enemies, and get a feel for which is appropriate in context, allowing an experienced player to feel more versatile than they did but an hour ago. The game is pretty, but you'll soon get tired of the 'unfolding vistas' approach to unlocking new areas - a constant of the experience. The last level utilised a wide-angled perspective, as in certain levels of Jotun, but it feels like it could've been better exploited on the preceding levels (not to say it doesn't serve a narrative function!). The narration is fairly on-point throughout, though I noticed at least one incident of the narrator saying one thing only to have the presumed protagonists' voice repeat it word for word. The progression is somewhat misaligned; I was being routinely prompted to upgrade my skills despite having all available ones maxed, and assuming you're playing for something of a completionist route, you'll find yourself at the same state as well.  

Achievements are well scaled and timed for the majority, but the outstanding 'Kill 10,000 bugs' and 'Write 1% of A Song of Ice and Fire' are both blegh. Typing "Gypsyism" is a curious experience.

If you have it setting in your Library from the Humble Monthly, you ought to give it a try. Otherwise, wait for a sale.

26556681.review:
It was a fantastic, though short journey. The main appeal of the game is obviously it's art style and rather rare (but not unique) gameplay - you interact with the world by typing in names of things. You need to freeze some water? Type in ICE, to swich to "Ice Mode", then Frost, to freeze the lake and walk though. Every nearby object has something written over it - freezing the water may require yout to type in Blizzard instead, and so on. I liked the extra touch that this works even in menus, as alterantive control over mouse or moving with keyboard from button to button.

The game is mainly about exploring this dreamlike (*wink*wink*) world on the back of your three tailed fox, as a little girl - trying to find out who you are, where you came from, and what is happening around you. You bring back life to forests, hurt by fire, and I really don't want to say anything else, because the game has so little to offer but it's so wonderful to explore it. Be sure to finish every picture collection you can, there is an unexpected twist at the end, and you'll be happy you collected them - also, the game's only story comes from you, the player, trying to figure out who our little hero is by the small clues the game gives.

[b]Summary[/b]: it's really a game for those who are open to minimalistic, artistic games, creative and rather unique gameplay you only find maybe in a couple of games, but you also have an above than average quality bar and look for little, ageless masterpieces rather than poorly executed good ideas. It lasted 4 hours for me (included ~0,5 hours having lunch), explored and collected everything I could aside from a single "dungeon" I did not know how to access. I went far above max level, unlocked every ability - I recommend you to upgrade exploration (map) and experience/combo related abilities first, so you don't need to backtrack too much later on. There is a survival arena mode in the main menu, if you are interested, but it's recommended only after finishing the game to preserve the atmopshere of the story.

[b]Recommended price[/b]: 9.99 max, anything below is an easy decision.

26458684.review:
Direi unico nel suo genere. Divertentissimo, intelligente, curato artisticamente. Ha tutte le carte in regola per risultare un giocone. Personalmente posso descriverlo come uno dei migliori giochi mai giocati!
Si tratta essenzialmente di un typing game, dove per interagire con lo scenario ed i nemici bisogna digitare la corretta sequenza di caratteri indicati su schermo, nel minor tempo possibile. A questo si aggiunge un gameplay simile a quello degli Zelda, con upgrade disponibili, per sbloccare location e sconfiggere i nemici in maniera più efficace. Otterremo difatti i poteri del fuoco, del ghiaccio, dell'elettricità, del vento, ognuno con peculiari caratteristiche ed inoltre potremo potenziarli.
Il gioco si presenta con una graditissima grafica 3D ad origami, molto molto particolare ma, data anche la varietà degli scenari, mai stancante.
Per completare il gioco nella sua interezza ci vogliono una decina di ore. Per ottenere tutti gli achievements bisogna ricorrere alle altre modalità di gioco e le ore incrementano di molto.

26394462.review:
When I think of action typing games the most prominent game that comes to mind is Typing of the Dead. A classic and there's been nothing close to it since, until now. Epistory takes you on an adventure through a paper landscape riding on a large origami fox. This game has those feverish typing to kill enemies element but this one is more family friendly.

When you start off it's not clear how or why you're in this strange paper world or what your end game is but that's okay as the game leads you down many paths to uncover your story. The more you explore the more your world expands. As you fight and type your way through enemies you gain points for unlocking more areas. Pretty straightforward right? As you make your journey through the vast wilderness your chronicles are narrated by the girl in a way that seems more like a walk through memory lane.

There are various zones throughout the world that break up the monotony and a couple of magic powers to provide a little variety for your typing skills. While this game is way more family friendly than the aforementioned title that no way diminishes the  hardcore difficulty of this game. You will periodically face waves of enemies and the words to defeat foes gets progressively more complex. There are some words I didn't even know existed in the English language. But I should also mention that if English isn't your go to native language don't fear as you can play in several different languages.

So to sum it up:

+Great art style 
+Several languages to choose from
+Innovative battle system
+Ability to make your own word lists

Okay the one issue I kind of had with this game was movement controls were a bit on the clunky side. It's played at a fixed isometric camera  view and you use AWSD keys to move but going in a straight line requires holding 2 keys and then there's another button for running. Yeah, that's the only thing I was not a fan of. But for everything else this game is a treasure and a definite must play even if typing games aren't your jam.

26369838.review:
[h1]Review zu Epistory - Typing Chronicles[/h1]

Epistory ist wie der Titel schon sagt ein "Typing" Spiel. Man spielt ein Mädchen das auf Ihrem Fuchs reitet und die Geschichte Ihres Lebens und Ihrer Vergangenheit wieder entdecken muss, weil alles in Vergessenheit geraten ist. Die Spielwelt besteht aus Papier worauf sich Zeichnungen und Wörter befinden. Die ganze Welt breitet sich vor dem Spieler aus und reagiert mit Veränderung auf Interaktionen. Diese Interaktionen werden mit Eingabe von Buchstaben oder Wörtern getätigt. Auch die Kämpfe werden mit "tippen" ausgeführt.
Ich war Anfangs etwas skeptisch dem Spiel gegenüber. Einerseits sah es in den YouTube Videos wirklich sehr schön aus, andererseits war mir das Genre fremd und ich hatte gewisse Vorurteile weil ich dachte, es könnte schnell langweilig werden.
Aber das Gegenteil war der Fall. Epistory zieht einen von der ersten Minute an in einen Bann. Die Sprecherstimme, die Spielwelt wie sie sich ausbreitet, die dauernden Veränderungen, die verschiedenen Gebiete und auch die Kämpfe....all das ist Fantastisch! Es gibt auch einen Fähigkeiten Skill Bereich, wo man die einzelnen Zauber die man erlernt auch noch verbessern kann.

[b]PROs[/b]
[list]
    [*]Wunderschönes Design
    [*]Tolle Atmosphäre ab der ersten Minute
    [*]viele Rätsel
    [*]sinnvolle Wörter, passen meistens zu den Objekten
    [*]herausfordernde "Wellen" Kämpfe
    [*]viele Steam Erfolge
[/list]

[b]CONTRAs[/b]
[list]
    [*]gibt´s nichts
 [/list]

[b]FAZIT[/b]
Ich habe dieses Spiel verschlungen und werde es sicher nochmal Spielen und versuchen, die Erfolge noch auf 100% zu bringen. Ich kann das Spiel wirklich jedem empfehlen, der mit dem Genre "Typing" oder "Rätsel" etwas anfangen kann. Wirklich ein ganz tolles Spiel.

26300943.review:
This is a gorgeous and amazing game! The animation is so creative and beautiful to look at. I also really love typing games and it is nice to see something that seems made for teens and adults to enjoy. The music is also pretty good, although it fades out a bit too much and the environmental effects become aggravating after a while. I would not recommend it for typing practice, unless you are pretty good and just want to practice speed. It probably also helps if you have a decent vocabulary. Sometimes the words get blurry and since it is better to hit them far off, knowing the word from the few letters you can see and the length helps you type it out and other times they are just very long words and being able to spell them out quickly then jump to others is a great help.

I only have two criticisms. The ice dungeon is frustrating, because for whatever reason the arrow keys don't aim well, but all the targets are very sensitive. Also, if you don't have the proper screen size the words relatively near the edge of the screen can be very hard to read, meaning that you're sometimes stuck typing at the last minute. This also is not really a criticism but I think I will have to play it again to really understand the story. It is not that complex and I think I get it, but there's a small plot hole I do not really understand. Also, the end credits song is not included in the purchaseable soundtrack for whatever reason.

It works just fine on the mac. I have a MacBook Pro 2012 and the colors looked great, framerate was good, and movement was just fine.

It is not a very long game, but it is a lot of fun. It is fun to explore and the attacks are really interesting. The idea of watching a world made out of paper folded out for you to see is wonderful.

I would recommend this for people who like typing and exploration games.

26166612.review:
Not many video games use spelling or typing as a game mechanic and Epistory: Typing Chronicles does it flawlessly. This genre is relatively small and the only other typing game that I've played is Mario Teaches Typing on DOS which taught me the very basics of keyboard usage. Epistory takes it to the next level in many ways and all of them good.

First, the words you'll type are relative to the game and it's story. This creates a pattern that eases you into typing some very long and challenging words. Second, gameplay is never stale. From the very beginning you'll see areas blocked off and you'll know to return to these areas later once you've acquired certain skills. Straight to the very end, you'll have to quickly switch between these skills to achieve your goals and, for many, this won't be an easy feat. Third, you can play this game entirely with your keyboard without ever taking your fingers off the home row. Menus can be traversed by simply typing the option you want to adjust which is slower than simply using your mouse, but I enjoyed being immersed in my typing experience. Lastly, the story and voice-acting are nice rewards for your progression. A narrator tells the story as you walk along and acts as a guide so you know when you're walking in the right direction. I shouldn't have to tell you that this game won't be remembered for its story; it's the gameplay that you're looking for here.

Overall, I had a great time playing Epistory. If you're looking for a unique game, different from your usual strategy, RPG, or action-adventure, look no further. You won't regret your purchase here.

26160148.review:
一言でいうと、タイピング アクション アドベンチャーゲーム。
少女を導き、折り紙でできたような世界を冒険する。

英語のタイピングゲームなので英単語の知識が必要になりますが、ちょっとくらい苦手でも大丈夫。

[h1]ゲームプレイ[/h1]
ゲームのメインはタイピングですが、アドベンチャーでもあります。
EFJIキーで移動し、スペースキーでタイピングモードを起動して、表示された文字を打つことでオブジェクトに対してアクションを起こします。
テキストはオブジェクトに関連がある言葉で、「今のぴったりじゃないか！」と思う言葉がたくさんあってとても楽しくプレイ出来ました。
また、要所要所では敵とのバトルもあり、八方からわらわら湧いてくる敵にタイピングで対抗するのですが、表示されている数以上に忙しいです。
というのも、敵には属性があって、火に弱い相手には火炎魔法、氷に弱い相手には氷結魔法を使わないと攻撃が通りません。
やわらかいけど素早い敵や、遅いけど硬い敵がいて、攻撃する順番も考えつつ凌いでいくのは急がし楽しかったです。
バトルだけを遊ぶアリーナモードもあって、スコアボードに対応しています。

火炎魔法で攻撃した敵がとても見にくくなったるのが不満でした。DoTキルを待つより次弾を撃った方が早いのに、途中でミスするとどこまで入力したかわからなくて。

タイピングだけではなく、ちょっとしたパズルや時限ギミックなんかもあります。ストーリーと上手く噛み合ってるギミックでよかったです。

難易度は6段階から選ぶこともできるし、プレイ内容によって自動調整することもできます。自動調整では必然的に自分の最大パフォーマンスを求められるので後半は頻繁にゲームオーバーになるかもしれませんが、そこを越えて60WPMを目指したいですね。

メニューはコンパニオンテキストといって、これまたタイピングで操作することになります。これは最初こそ目新しさがあって楽しく操作できていたんですが、コンフィグの深い部分が対応しておらずマウス操作するしかなかったり、そこそこの長さの単語を何度も打ち込むのが面倒だったりして、すこし不満に感じました。
単語補完とか矢印キーによる操作もあればよかったですね。

[h1]ストーリー[/h1]
物語のテキストは穴だらけになっていて、断定できることはとても少ないです。
導入部分で「少女がいた。大きな狐に乗っていた。すべてが失われていた」と語られていますが、少女が狐に乗っていることは明らかでも、何を指して「失われていた」のか、エンディングを見た今でも確信を持てません。
しかし、ひとつの場面を切り取って見てみると、その瞬間の映像とナレーションはとてもよく合っていて、情景を描き出しています。
プレイヤー自身が想像力を働かせて、自分だけの物語を作る、そういう意図があるんでしょう。

[h1]ヴィジュアル[/h1]
KAMIというゲームがありますが、未知のエリアを解放するとあんな感じでぱたぱたーっと世界が拡がっていきます。
構造物は地面からにょきにょき生えてくるだけなので、もっと折り紙やペーパークラフトのような動きがあるともっとよかったですね。開発は大変そうですが。

[h1]ローカライズ[/h1]
日本語は今後のアップデートで実装予定。
ベータプログラムに参加することで一足先に日本語でプレイが可能です。
ただ、ベータなのでフォントの問題で読めない部分があったり、入力できずにリスタートするしかないこともあります。一応はクリア可能です。
ゲームプレイでタイピングする部分とストーリーテキストはそれぞれ別に言語設定を変えることが可能です。
日本語メニューでもコンパニオンテキストはないのでつけて欲しいんですが、まあでも使わなくなるならいらないかも？
ローカライズの品質はなかなかに高いのですが、前述の穴だらけストーリーの都合、どうしてもすっきりしないと思うことがありました。フィードバックで直るといいですが……期待して待っていましょう！

[h1]おわりに[/h1]
ナレーションはゲームのモブ役や日本アニメの吹き替えをされている Rachael Messer。物語を感情豊かに読み上げてくれています。

いくつか不満はありましたが、ゲームプレイは十分面白く、ロケーションも美しいので、時間を忘れて一気にエンディングまでいけました。最初に言ったように英単語知識がないと素早い入力はできませんが、ちょっとくらい苦手でも低い難易度ならクリア可能だと思います。近いうちに日本語が実装されますし、これは見逃せない作品だと思います！

26021981.review:
De entre los juegos mecanográficos que hay en Steam, este título resalta en muchos aspectos pues es un juego de aventura con una mezcla de habilidades mientras luchas contra enemigos con palabras sobre ellos, acompañado de un bello arte estilo origami. 

Uno de los aspectos más llamativos es que si configuras el juego a español, éste incluirá palabras con acentos y trabalenguas que son casi imposibles de deletrear. Dependiendo de la situación o el tipo de enemigo podrás cambiar el tipo de elemento de ataque al escribir su nombre, haciéndolo un juego de no solo escribir. La historia es enigmática e interesante, pues vas escuchando pasajes conforme entras a áreas nuevas muy al estilo de Dear Esther.

Los logros a desbloquear son bastante interesantes, pues dependiendo de la cantidad de palabras escritas, te hace saber en qué proporción se comparan las palabras que escribes en total contra obras muy extensas de la literatura universal. ¿Quieres más reto? intenta sobrepasar el record de 60 palabras por minuto o llegar a teclear hasta 1000 letras sin cometer ningún error; difícil si lo tuyo no son los acentos al teclear.

Muy recomendado para todos los niveles de pericia en la mecanografía, pues la dificultad se adapta dependiendo de la velocidad y el índice de errores que cometas según vayas avanzando. Una compra obligada si te gustaron juegos como "The Typing of the Dead.

26018946.review:
When I watched trailers for this game for the first time, I got the impression that the writing would be very literary, very highbrow, and a central part of the game. The trailers certainly try to imply that. In actuality, the writing is not that great, and almost tumblry at times. Although I will concede, that, a lot of it being in the form of disjointed sentences makes it harder to appraise. And also, the writing coming out of the protagonist in such disjointed sentences, one at a time, makes sense in the context of the story. Speaking of which...

The plot twist at the end of the game has got to be the oldest cliché in the, ahem, book. So much so, that people are reluctant to use it nowadays, which is a good thing. So when I saw the ending of Epistory, I literally did a mental triple take:

[quote][i]...Really? They actually went with it, the absolute madmen? Are you serious? No, but like... really?[/i][/quote]

Ultimately, it doesn't make the game less satisfying, but I found it disapointing. A bit. The way the initial chapters play out, I was imagining the story is about a young novelist struggling with writer's block, trying to regain her inspiration or maybe a more literal search for a missing muse. But no.

Luckily, the gameplay is solid. The adaptive difficulty does a good job of picking a difficulty level for you, or you can manually choose out of like... five, I think. The graphics are gorgeous; the origami world "unfolding before your eyes" gimmick doesn't really get old. The audio is okay. The puzzles are so simple that at first I found them insulting, but as time went on, I warmed up to this emanation of casualness. There aren't that many typing games out there, so a new entry into the genre and as well-polished as this always makes me pleased. In terms of content it doesn't match up to the likes of The Typing of The Dead, but I don't mind.

25955519.review:
If you're like me and have grown far more fond of these indie games that don't last for more than 12 hours than any AAA game, then know that Epistory is one of these little gems that you will love. 

The gameplay is one of these ideas that has been seen before, but that's perfectionned here to make a very enjoyable experience : typing to get through the puzzles and fights, and even through the menus and upgrade system if you wish. The graphics are original, and very nice to look at although they lose some of their original impact as the game goes on.

But what will make you look back and smile after you finish the game is the story. The narration is perfect, delivered through both the voice-over and the gameplay, as even the words you'll need to type to destroy enemies will send a different vibe depending on what point in the story you are at. The rhythm too is great, I found myself making and scrapping theories all along, wondering where this lovely game was leading me throughout the whole experience. Every "dungeon" is memorable on its own, and its particular aspects make sense in the story as much as in the gameplay.

In short : Epistory is worth buying at full price despite is short length if you have the money for it, as supporting this kind of innovative devs is something you should do ;) If you're a little bit tight on money, wait for it to go on sale and jump at it.

25950470.review:
I bought this game because I’m learning BÉPO and I wanted something to practice with. I thoroughly enjoyed playing it through to the end. By far the best thing about this game is the art style and the pleasing paper effects when a new area unravels. It seems the game is somewhat inspired by Zelda-style games with a large map and several dungeons to explore. However I think this comparison sets you up for disappointment because it is lacking several elements which the real Zelda games do much better. The story begins by building up a lot of intrigue but in the end it doesn’t really seem to go anywhere and the random snippets of narration don’t really connect together. Like a Zelda game there are a few puzzle elements but in practice the puzzles are relatively easy and there are only a few different ideas which are repeated. In the dungeons you can find new magic powers and they have done a good job of making these interesting. All of them are useful in different circumstances. It would have been nice if they could have made more use of these powers in the puzzles or made the boss battles require the magic in interesting ways like when you gain a new item in Zelda. Sadly there aren’t really any bosses in Epistory and there are only a handful of different enemy types which are repeated over and over in different combinations.

I found the game relatively easy despite my typing speed still being a pitiful 20WPM. I wonder if this could be because the automatic difficulty adjustment recognised my terrible typing speed but didn’t manage to adjust as I improved. The first few nests were extremely difficult but for most of the later ones I was able to beat them on my first attempt.

Regardless of the criticism in my review I still highly recommend the game mostly because the innovative typing mechanic is such a joy to play. I hope one day they will be able to work on the idea and make an even cooler sequel.

25938804.review: Pretty entertaining game.  It was difficult but not frustrating. It was pretty short though although I didn't collect everything i could have.  I got this game through the humble bundle.

25934223.review:
Wow. Okay, I've played my fair range of typing games, ranging from the mundane to *this*. You may think, "how original can you get with a typing game? Is it worth buying this?" This is how original you can get with a typing game.

A story told not by a heavy-fisted hand but by respecting your intelligence and giving you the pieces to put the story together in your head, in a sense leaving the player to *write* the story themselves. A typing system lenient enough as to not frustratingly punish the player for the endless typos you will make in the intense battle sections, but hard enough to make this an extremely rewarding challenge that does actually make you markedly better at typing. A world so beautiful and varied that I even enjoyed the endless backtracking, I seemingly unturned new stones with every step I walked. A narrator you will never get tired of hearing the voice of, and neither the words. A pacing so well done that even through the many play sessions it took to get through the game, it still felt like a cohesive journey to the very end.

If you are decent at typing and have the money to spare, buy this game. I don't think you'll regret it.

25862506.review:
Received this as a gift, and went in with little knowledge or expectation.  Having now played through it, I must say, it was a pleasant surprise out of nowhere.

While the principle is simple: It's a typing-based game, where you type words to attack enemies that move toward you.  It plays out quite nicely and adds an elemental dynamic that keeps you on your toes, essentially shifting modes to attack specific enemies, and with each element having bonus effects that can make attacking "Neutral" enemies easier or quicker. 

That aside, the game is also very beautifully presented with a pleasing art style very similar to a pop-up picture book with a little bit of papercraft mixed in.  As you play, the map slowly unfolds (Quite literally!) from words on a page to reveal new areas and unique puzzles to solve as you work your way to uncovering the fox-riding protagonist's hidden story.  


I'd say it's about 5-6 hours long if you don't go TOO crazy about collectable hunting. Maybe a bit more if you're a completionist. Consider nabbing it in a sale or if you want something to suit your fancy over a weekend binge.  You're unlikely to regret it, if you're OK with the style of gameplay.

I loved this game! It was beautiful, intriguing, challenging and fun. I'm so impressed! The worlds were so varied. It was a joy to watch the pages unfolding when you unlocked a new area of the map. 

The game didn't get boring at all, even though all you really do is run around and type words to open stuff and kill stuff. The puzzles are enough to let you ponder, but not make you struggle. 

The typing battles really got my heart pumping, helped by the great music score. I liked the different powers, and how you had to go through a new world to get it, and that the world had the same theme as the power you were picking up. As in ice world for the ice power etc. I also liked the detail that the words to type for each power were words assosiated with it. For instance all the words to type using the ice power were words such as: snow, winter, glacier, cold, shivering etc. And for fire it was: hot, fireplace, stove, sun, blazing etc. 

Highly recommended if you like a beautiful game based on story, writing, and books. 
And of course, you have to like to type! It felt so satisfying killing that big monster that had echocardiogram, photosensitivity, multimillionairs, and cinematograpy as the "killing words". Of course, at the same time all those little f*ckers came at me with their short words, ilk, axe, woe, ill, die, hat, mad, bow, tax, fee, foe, cat....... I'm just relieved that I didn't have to write this review on a timer!

25801183.review:
This game has style.

Epistory is a typing game, entirely controlled with the keyboard and an interesting internal dictionary.

Unlike a game like typing of the dead, you fully control a character on a 2D plane, moving through a storybook land as it's built around you.  When you come across barriers you must type out a word highlighted in the world, which will cast a spell and destroy whatever is blocking your path.  The same principal applies with enemies.  This constitutes the central mechanic through which the game is played, and despite my initial difficulties in reconciling the 4 way directions with the 45 degree camera view (you'll see what I mean if you check out a video) it didn't take long to get to grips with.

The quirky mechanics aside, the main attraction of this game is the story.  The fantastical art direction and simple narration give the entire world an endearing momentum that swept me along during my playtime.

In this game the story is the thing, and that story is punctuated by an immaculate style that suits it to a tee.

It falls into the niche typing game genre, but really, it's just a [i]damned good game[/i].

25783399.review:
This is an all around excellent game that takes keyboarding as a gameplay mechanic and rolls with it gracefully. 

The graphics have a delightful paper stylization that unfolds and forms as you explore the world.  Gameplay remains fresh by integrating a leveling up system, implementing 4 elemental powers and puzzles.  The player switches between powers by typing the relevant word: fire, ice, wind or spark.  Some enemies can only be harmed by certain elements and each elemental attach has it's own perks such as fire burning the next word in a que and spark bouncing to hurt multiple enemies when it attachs an enemy with multiple words in the que.  Total I went through the game fairly quickly coming in around 6 hours (not finding and doing everything but completing the main story).

25766849.review:
I got this game out of a humble bundle, and was pretty interested in the concept, as I've always been a fan of writing and typing games.
The graphics and overall artstyle were beautiful and felt unique. 
The overall gameplay got a bit tedious at times, and movement outside of combat felt a bit like a drawn-out fetch-quest.
That said, the combat was very enjoyable and continued to be interesting and engaging up until the end. 

In regards to the ending and overarching plot, I'll be honest - I loathed it. The narration right from the start sounded very pretentious, and tried too hard to be profound. It worked somewhat as an auditory aid to the gameplay, but then towards the end the game suddenly tried to make out that the narration meant something. 
While I'd been a bit dettered by the "plot", I still enjoyed the game up until the end. I'm sure different people will view it in different ways, but I was pretty infuriated by the incredibly cliché closing cinematic - so much so that I felt compelled to share my thoughts on it.

If you're considering buying this game based on the gameplay and elegance, then by all means it really delivers.
However, if you're looking primarily for a good story, then I'd suggest finding something else.

All in all, I get the impression that this was made with a pretty limited budget and the devs were able to successfully mask that fact in most aspects of the game. I bought it at a discount and I don't regret the purchase.

25727777.review:
[b]Short Version:[/b]  [i] Vibrant /  Enigmatic / Innovative / Enchanting / Origami / Qwertyopolis  / Bastion-esque  / Yummy like a donut  /  Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious / Fun! [/i]  
Now type all that as fast as you can and imagine evil bugs melting while a beautiful paper world and magical story unfold around you with every word.  Huzzah, you just played my homemade Epistory demo!

Epistory is a lovely adventure game in which the keyboard is mightier than the sword.  You control a girl who rides a giant fox and has the power to fight off villainous baddies and reshape nature itself through words.  As you explore the mysterious world around you, you are both guided and followed by the melodious narration of your own story, which lures you ever deeper into the unknown.

Epistory's gameplay is wonderfully unique - you wander around on your giant fox, solving simple puzzles and magically eliminating any obstacles and enemies in your path by typing words that float above them.   You earn experience points by completing these typing challenges, and can earn many more points by rapidly completing multiple typing tasks in a combo.  Once you level up, you can develop various abilities that will help you better explore the world or chain longer word-combos.

The gameplay might end up feeling a bit repetitive (explore, solve simple puzzles, type floating words), but the added skill progression through leveling up, along with developing new magical spells as you continue through the game definitely helps alleviate that.  Meanwhile, the world itself is a joy to explore.  The colorful visuals are gorgeously lush, with a unique paper-art style that meshes perfectly with the story and gameplay.  The audio is also well done, with quality voice acting and pleasant background music that changes to fit your current situation.  

[b]Conclusion:[/b]  
Epistory is simply brilliant.  It is one of those games that does something so weird and new and does it so well that you'll remember it fondly years down the road.  Do yourself a favor, and give this remarkable game a try.

[quote]Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes.  This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/[/quote]

While somewhat dramatic at times, this game has a lovely way of allowing the user to relate to the character. Even with the gender difference between myself and the main character, I feel connected.

25716308.review:
I never thought a typing game could be so unique, beautiful and inspiring.

I received this game as part of my monthly subscription to Humble Bundle, and I though it looked nice enough to give it a try. I was hook almost instantly thanks to the amazing music and the stylish paper-like visual design. The narration is another great part that keeps the game going forward. It reminded me of Bastion, both thanks to the narration and the way the world unfolds before you.

The gameplay itself is an interesting take on the dungeon crawler genre, but instead of swords or magic, you type words on your keyboard that correspond to a certain enemy. It's a pretty simple system, but Epistory manages to keep it versatile by adding different types of powers and puzzles. The combat can get a little repetitive at times, especially when you fight waves and waves of enemies, but that's the only bad thing I can really say.

Bottom line: great indie gem.

25712147.review:
Epistory is a beautiful handcrafted game for which you explore an isometric landscape, exploring dungeons and of course type to destroy the infestation. How well does this work in motion? Surprisingly very well. The controls for moving your character may be a tad awkward initially -- it offers WASD but I found it to be inferior to using the game's recommended controls of ijfe which seem to be tighter. However once you get over that, you will find the game is very expertly crafted. Menu items, etc are all typable meaning that your hands will never need to leave your keyboard. 

The game is challenging mostly in your speed of typing and lack of errors. If you make too many errors, your progress on a word will be reset. Towards the end of the game you are often sent a lot of enemies at once. There are powers which can help alleviate some stress however typing quickly and reading the screen quickly are very necessary. 

The art style of the game is beautiful. Very reminiscent of orgami/paper mache. The animations are all very well done. Especially when revealing parts of the map. 

Cons:
- Controls are initially awkward at first / WASD is less tight
- Map can be useless at times. I found it really hard to read in dungeons especially.
- Is a tad short (~4 hours for me to beat the story skipping two dungeon areas, with the rest of my hours doing achievements/completion)

Neben den Gegnern gilt es immer wieder kleine und meist einfache Rätseleinlagen zu lösen. Nach und nach deck man so die Weltkarte auf und verbessert seine Fähigkeiten.

3/5

25641199.review:
Después de terminar Epistory, creo que me ha hecho sentir lo suficiente como para dedicarle un análisis apartado por apartado. 
La verdad es que me ha sorprendido bastante este juego. Me lo compré por curiosidad, nunca había oído hablar de el y no sabía qué iba a encontrarme.
Para empezar ya os digo que merece su precio, aunque como siempre, podéis adquirirlo en otras páginas mucho más barato.

GRÁFICOS:
Lo primero que llama la atención del juego es su apartado visual. Está todo hecho de papel. Los personajes, los escenarios. Todo. Y la verdad es que se ve bastante bonito.
Los paisajes son coloristas y variados, y el toque minimalista del origami le da una belleza muy particular.
8/10

JUGABILIDAD:
Es lo segundo que llama la atención del juego, y la verdad es que al principio me pareció un poco extraño, y no sabía cómo funcionaba exactamente.
Pero después de probarlo, tengo que decir que es lo más original que he visto en mucho tiempo, funciona bien, es divertido, adictivo, y satisfactorio.
De lo que estoy hablando, es que, en vez de golpear, seleccionar comandos, pulsar botones para hacer determinada acción como en otros juegos, lo que tenemos que hacer aquí es escribir.
Sí, escribir palabras para ser concretos.
Hay elementos en el mapa que podemos modificar o destruir, y para ello tenemos que escribir palabras que están relacionadas con ese elemento.
Para luchar, aparecen varios enemigos en pantalla, y los más fuertes requerirán más palabras y más complejas para ser derrotados.
Puede parecer raro, pero cuando hay muchos enemigos, y no puedes parar de teclear palabras para derrotarlos....es pura adrenalina, ya os lo digo.
9/10

HISTORIA:
La historia se nos cuenta en frases que aparecen por el mapa, y por fragmentos de fotos que vamos encontrando por las diferentes mazmorras. 
Al principio puede parecer bastante misteriosa, quizá liosa. Y es que yo pienso que hay demasiadas líneas de texto y demasiado misterio para contar una historia tan simple. 
Admito que mientras iba recogiendo los fragmentos, y descubriendo nuevas imágenes, me sentía intrigado por la historia que había detrás. Pero al final, después de tanto misterio, de tantas líneas de diálogo abstractas y algo confusa, simplemente me pareció que se habían sacado el final de la manga.
Pero la historia no es lo importante en este juego. Es bonito ir descubriéndola, y os aconsejo recoger todos los fragmentos. Pero vaya, que no es lo que vais a recordar de este juego, ni mucho menos.
6/10

MÚSICA: 
Lamentablemente, la música está muy ausente en este juego. 
Cierto es que hay numerosas pistas, pero sólo aparecen en determinados momentos del juego, y con una intensidad mínima. A veces no te das ni cuenta de que está sonando, básicamente porque estás más pendiente en lo que estás haciendo que en otra cosa. Porque como ya he dicho, está muy en segundo plano. Por eso no puedo valorar al 100% la banda sonora de este juego, aunque lo que he escuchado, simplemente cumple.
Son temas relajantes, furiosos en las batallas, y poco más. Nada destacable.
7/10

DURACIÓN:
Más largo de lo que me esperaba.
La verdad es que es un mapa bastante grande, el cual vamos desbloqueando poco a poco, a medida que vamos acumulando puntos de experiencia.
También hay secretos, zonas opcionales, batallas opcionales, coleccionables, etc.
Este es un juego para ir lento, ir descubriéndolo todo y aprovecharlo al máximo.
Para ser lo que es, la duración es aceptable. Las horas que tengo es el tiempo exacto en el que he tardado en pasármelo.
7/10

CONCLUSIÓN:
Esto es lo que he considerado aceptable para analizar del juego, más apartados son innecesarios, pues o son escasos o inexistentes. Así que, aquí va mi conclusión sobre Epistory.
Si tuviera que definir a Epistory en tres palabras, serían: Divertido, Variado y Completo.
Divertido porque sus mecánicas, el tema de la exploración del mapa, las mazmorras, coleccionables etc le dan mucha acción al juego. Es difícil que llegue a aburrirte si realmente te ha gustado.
Variado por la de cosas que puedes hacer cuando creía que iba a ser un juego de lo más básico. Habilidades, poderes, batallas opcionales, cofres ocultos, fragmentos para conocer la historia, zonas muy variadas, etc.
Completo porque es un juego redondo. Ofrece una manera original de jugarlo, una duración considerable, no demasiada historia, que a veces es un punto positivo, y visualmente te va a agradar mucho. 
Finalmente, mi recomendación es que sí, debes jugar Epistory. No va a ser un juego que vayas a recordar más allá de su jugabilidad, pero el rato que pases jugando, te divertirás bastante y te dará gusto verlo en tu biblioteca.

Nota media: 7,4
Nota personal: 7,5

25630706.review:
I enjoy typing. I was not expecting this sort of typing, and its actually better than whatever I could say I was expecting. Its a paper-woven story about an overreactive girl on a massive fox that casts magical spells to kill insects and only insects.

The game unfolds before you as a real story would, and it looks lovely to boot. There are ideas where you can burn away brambles to continue on, or destroy cobwebs to improve the area.

You'll never be without the inspiration that you need so like, the idea of having said checkpoints to open more of the map for you is honestly kinda silly. You get four elements though, Spark, Ice, Fire, and WInd, I'm guessing.
I'm guessing because I gave up on it.

See, after every 'level', you find this circle. You go stand in the circle, and foes will begin to attack you. Now, where I was, you gotta keep these crystals lit or else you can't see the words you must type in, to kill these bugs, and there are five crystals with pretty medium sized words, and the bugs can come in five directions.
Its fine. its a challenge. Artifical maybe, but I can go with it.

But the game hype cancels you! 
You spend a solid 30 seconds waiting for the bugs to come again, and in the meantime the crystals die out. So you gotta go and re-light them and OH LOOK its a swarm of bugs that die with just a letter. Its not. Fun.
Its not fun to stare at the screen dully waiting for what you know is coming. It doesn't create suspence, cuz you've seen this done many times. It just kills your flow and creates difficultly for you.
Its not even hard! Its just dirty. They literally just....make things difficult for you.
Its like trying to cross a narrow path, and suddenly and unexpectedly, BAM a rock falls through and destroys the path. You have no way to know when its gonna happen, or why.
If i can blame the game for something, You know its serious.
And I can. I do not blame the game for my own faults. I could type faster among other things.
However. No speed will stop the hype canceling. Its just gonna keep happening, and Its truely pathetic.

Everything else is actually amazing. Including the Narration and story.

7/10

25592746.review:
Pre-TL;DR: Epistory is such a rarity in that it handles a unique gameplay style so intuitively that in no moment does the game feel overly gimmicky. Responsive controls, cathartic gameplay, rewarding world, inventive powerups, and an interesting story. When Typing of the Dead is the main competition, I highly recommend you pick up Epistory.

PROS:
- Satisfying gameplay. I have gotten the most use out of my Corsair K70 keyboard playing this game than I have doing anything else on my PC. Even if you don't have a mechanical keyboard, killing waves of bugs with efficient typing attacks feels so amazing.
- Clever controls. The game recommends using E,F, J, and I to control your character through the overworld so you can seamlessly switch between moving and typing, which feels very natural. Also, fun little typing interactions like spamming R and U over and over again to simulate forcing a lock on a chest, and ASDF for turning a crank were some of my favorite moments of the game.
- Beautiful, diverse world full of secrets. The world is made of paper and origami, with the story literally being written on the stage. It's extremely rewarding to explore and unlock new areas to see everything the game has to offer. Great game for completionists (good luck with those "Diamond in the Rough" achievements though).
- Fun powerups. Throughout the game you gain 4 powerups that not only help you progress but aid with all types of battle. Often times you'll have to switch back and forth between powerups, so no power is ever made obsolete.

CONS:
- Can get repetitive during longer playtimes. The main objectives of this game are to 1.) Destroy waves of bugs and 2.) Solve puzzles to continue through the world. I only played this game for 1 to 2 hour sessions at a time, so I really didn't mind this and found every instance to be engaging. But if you like to binge your games, this might be a drawback.
- Kind of short. As of writing this I have 7 hours of gameplay, with about 1 hour being only the arena mode (which is so fun). Again, if you like to binge your games, you might beat this in one sitting. However, an indie game with 7 hours of gameplay is generally okay in my book regardless.
- Not terribly challenging. Maybe I'm just amazing at typing, but I didn't find the game to be all that challenging. I also wish the level cap was a bit higher. I was able to unlock all of the upgrades before the last dungeon.

25499429.review:
This game mixes a rather unique thing (the typing) with a familiar thing. The result is interesting, though I'm not sure if there is any synergie between the two.
The main mechanic is the unique thing: you attack by typing words. Once you come near chests, objects or enemies, words appear above it. By correctly typing that word (and usually a couple following words) on your keyboard, you wipe it out. It's strange and at times pretty bizarre, but it works. I'm not sure how this mechanic works if you barely know how to type - there's a difficulty-adjusting mechanic, but I don't know how well-tailored it'll be for others - but it certainly hit a sweet difficulty spot on my end.
The familiar thing is the story and narration. You're a girl on a fox for some reason who is on a quest to...erm...to restore...erm...okay, it doesn't make much sense when I tell it, but it's captivating, well told and the papier mache aesthetics are absolutely gorgeous. The world is Zelda-ish with treasures, enemies and ways to expand things. The latter is usually by reaching a certain experience-index or a newly gained power found in a dungeon-of-sort. The narration is great as well.

So...these are two things I like. Do I like the combination? Erm...mostly. It's a fun (and even educational!) mechanic, but I honestly don't see it match with the storytelling part. Why do I open a gate by typing "AZER" four times? (for those wondering: it has support for other keyboard layouts). How does killing something by typing a word work? Why does that huge bug fly around with a "incendiary"-word above it? I won't lie: it's a gamy mechanic that distracts. On the other hand, it's important to stress that both parts in themselves are absolutely good enough - perhaps even better than they should be - to carry the game. As such, it deserves my thumbs up.

25493890.review:
Páni, tak toto jsem opravdu nečekal. Očekával jsem obyčejnou, nudnou a krátkou psací hru, nicméně jsem byl překvapen opakem. Základ hry je, že postupně odemykáte mapu tím, jak procházítě prostředím, zabíjíte potvory psaním a pomalu expíte postavu. Prostředí, které procházíte vypadá nádherně a rozhodně není repetetivní. Okolí dokresluje povedené ozvučení a soundtrack.

+achivementy, kartičky, lokalizace (možná trošku zvyšuje obtížnost česka diakritika)
+obtížnost, která se přizpůsobuje
+odkrývání mapy, dabing, zvuky prostředí, zvhled prostředí

25485204.review:
Zelda teaches typing is the easiest way I can explain this one. If that sounds interesting and you can touch type, this is well worth a look even at full price. If you can't already touch type, it's not going to make any effort to teach you, and certain areas are almost definitely going to be impossbile unless you're *very* fast at hunting and pecking. 

Gameplay consists of wondering around the world and typing words to kill or activate stuff. There are four main dungeons that add elemental powers to your typing and four sub-dungeons that offer more challenging and creative uses of the powers. Both dungeon types have fully optional image fragments to collect, which is usually fun enough to be worthwhile. There are also something like 24 Nests between the overworld and dungeons that offer a progressively more difficult rush of enemies coming from all directions. These are the hardest and most enjoyable parts of the game.

Even as someone who loves abstract stories, I found this one too abstract to be enjoyable. I think it got lost in a lot of its own metaphors and made a huge mistake in not revealing the frame until the end. It doesn't detract from the game, but I don't think it added anything. 

The soundtrack is basic, but decent enough. Ambient noises are very well done. I had some seemingly arbitrary frame rate dips early on, but otherwise it performs and looks acceptable. 

I've only got two real complaints: The electric chaining on the Spark power is unpredictable to the point of being useless, particularly if you want to get the no mistakes for X characters achievements. Second, the game does not check if one enemy's active word is a substring of another active word. This doesn't break the game, but it's very annoying when you start typing, for example, "barren" only for the game to instead attack the less dangerous enemy with "bar." I believe the intended behavior in this instance is to shoot the shorter enemy while maintaining your progress against the other, but I had numerous cases where only the shorter enemy got shot and I had to start typing the longer word from the beginning again.
