23200625.review:
Après avoir testé Epistory pendant sa période Early Access, je dois bien avouer que j'étais tombé sous le charme de l'univers mais aussi de l'idée générale. Un jeu d'exploration où l'on combat des ennemis avec son clavier, ce n'est certes pas nouveau mais il faut bien avouer que l'on avait pas encore vu de jeu de ce genre avec une telle réalisation et une thématique aussi forte. On contrôle donc la muse d'un écrivain qui tente de retrouver ses idées et ainsi avancer dans son histoire, tout un programme!

Ce qui frappe en premier dans Epistory - Typing Chronicles, c'est la réalisation graphique léchée et délicate, on se régale devant ces décors en origami qui se révèle à nous au fur et à mesure de notre progression. Nos héros sont particulièrement bien faits avec de belles animations et un design au top. Les ennemies, des insectes, valent eux-aussi le détour même si on peut regretter un certain manque de variété dans le bestiaire après 4-5 heures d'exploration. Un autre point très important de l'histoire vient de la forte présence de la narratrice qui nous raconte ce qu'il se passe dans cet univers. Le travail effectué par la comédienne est remarquable, mine de rien il constitue un des plus gros points forts du jeu au même titre que les réalisation graphique et sonore. On ressent particulièrement bien l'implication et la mise en avant de ce que peut ressentir notre personnage au niveau émotionnel.

Epistory - Typing Chronicles raconte donc une histoire intéressante de façon originale, on va devoir explorer l'esprit d'un écrivain et ouvrir des pages de sa mémoire en combattant des parasites, représentés par des insectes, qu'il faudra détruire grâce à la puissance des mots. En effet, chaque créature se voit attribuer un nom et il faudra le saisir au clavier pour détruire la dite créature. Bien entendu, tout n'est pas si simple et certaines créatures ont plusieurs mots qu'il faudra saisir à la suite pour pouvoir les éliminer.

Le jeu se contrôle au clavier, on utilise les touches ZQSD pour se déplacer et on appuis ensuite sur la touche Entrée pour saisir les mots. On peut également commencer un mot et en changer dans la foulée si l'on se rend compte que le danger vient d'une autre créature. En effet, dans Epistory - Typing Chronicles on peut se faire tuer, pour celà il suffit de se faire toucher une fois par une créature. Elles se rapprochent de nous à une vitesse liée au type de créature et le jeu étant bien fait, les créatures les plus rapides auront des mots courts ou simples! Si l'on peut se déplacer pour éviter que le contact soit fatal, il arrivera à certains moments clés que l'on ne puisse pas bouger et que l'on doivent affronter des vagues de créatures dont la seule issue sera soit notre victoire soit notre défaite.

Il n'y a pas que les créatures qui sont dotés de mots, certains éléments du décor en sont pourvus eux-aussi. Il faudra parfois détuire des éléments du décor pour avancer ou pour débloquer des coffres nous octroyant des points nécessaires à l'évolution de notre renard mais aussi nous permettant de débloquer de nouvelles zones du jeu. La difficulté du jeu est du coup progressive ce qui permet de ne pas être frustré trop vite par certains passages plus complexes que d'autres. Plus on réussi de mots sans se tromper et plus on augmente son taux de combo, celui nous permettant de gagner plus de points par rencontre ennemie, cette jauge de combo se vide au fil du temps ce qui nous obligera parfois à se déplacer rapidement pour aller trouver de nouveaux monstres à combattre ou de nouveaux éléments du décor à éradiquer.

Plus on gagnera de niveaux et plus on débloquera de points qui nous permettront à leur tour de débloquer des compétences et autres bonus passifs. La progression reste linéaire même si on peut parfois se demander où il faut aller car la carte
présente dans le jeu n'est pas très pratique à lire en ce qui concerne la prochaine zone à débloquer. On trouve également des donjons bonus nous permettant de gagner des points afin de débloquer de nouvelles zones. Epistory - Typing Chronicles est d'ailleurs plutôt bien fait au niveau de sa présentation des nouvelles mécaniques de jeu. On apprend de façon logique tous les rouages du jeu et on ne se frottera à des murs de difficulté que si l'on n'est pas là où l'on devrait être.

Il faut savoir que l'on peut choisir entre différents pouvoirs qui ont des effets différents sur les créatures, on peut les bruler, les repousser, les glacer ou les attaquer avec un effet de zone. Pour changer d'effet, il faudra entrer un mot spécifique comme Feu, glace, vent ou foudre. Certains monstres et autres éléments du décor nécessitent un effet particulier pour être détruits. Si on rencontre des caractères illisibles, c'est que l'on n'a pas encore débloqué le dit pouvoir. Pour ceux qui aiment terminer à 100% un jeu, Epistory - Typing Chronicles propose un sacré challenge car il y a énormément de secrets et d'achievements plus ou moins simples à débloquer.

Le jeu dispose d'un système de difficulté bien pensé et qui s'adapte en temps réel à notre niveau, autant dire que ceux qui se débrouillent bien auront plus de mal à terminer le jeu que les autres. A titre personnel, le jeu s'est durci assez rapidement et j'ai eu toutes les peines du monde à me sortir d'une arène vers le premier tiers du jeu. Après 2 échecs, Epistory - Typing Chronicles a fortement réduit la difficulté de ce passage ce qui m'a permis de continuer sereinement. La difficulté dynamique a tout de même quelques ratés car la fin du jeu est bien plus simple que le début une fois que l'on a tous les pouvoirs. Le changement d'effets est parfois compliqué à cause des accents mais c'est tout de même réalisable.

Au niveau de la réalisation, Epistory - Typing Chronicles est superbe! Le jeu est fluide sur une configuration correcte (Geforce 760) et il n'y pas de gros soucis en terme de bugs à noter. Mention spéciale à la musique qui est excellente et qui mérite d'être achetée en DLC. Le jeu prend en compte énormément de langues différentes ce qui est un gros plus étant donné le style de jeu. Je n'ai pas eu de gros problèmes en matière de puzzles ou de blocages, tout est logique ou alors il ne suffit parfois que de quelques minutes pour comprendre ce que l'on attend de nous. Au pire, je pesterais sur la maniabilité dans les sections de glace où l'on doit patiner d'une zone à une autre. La durée de vie est excellente grâce au mode histoire mais aussi au mode Arène. Le jeu se verra bientôt doté d'une mise à jour Workshop ce qui augmentera d'autant plus sa durée de vie.

Epistory - Typing Chronicles est un excellent jeu qui ne souffre que de quelques écueils. Il est beau, intéressant à suivre et surtout doté d'un jeu d'acteur qui apporte un énorme plus à l'ensemble. C'est également un jeu qui nous aide à mieux taper au clavier et à apprendre à ne plus regarder son clavier lorsque l'on tape. Je ne le conseille toutefois pas aux plus jeunes car la difficulté est réelle et il faut être bien attentif à ce qui arrive sur notre héroïne. Il faut prendre les bonnes décisions ce qui implique une dimension stratégique que l'on n'aurait pas soupçonné de prime abord.

23160522.review: What a fantastic little game! It's gorgeous and remarkably engaging. I just lost a half a day to playing through the whole story basically non-stop. The typing aspect as a user interface never detracts from the experience. In fact, it actually brings you further into the story. It creates a unique experience and causes you to become more personally involved. This is an excellent use of the medium. I just wish there were more games like this.

23133243.review:
This game is absolutely delightful! I've not had so much fun with a game in a long while. It feels like a "casual game" in some sense, with only basic exploration and a really relaxing atmosphere with great music and a giant fox. And then you get thrown into an arena with spiders and wasps trying to murder you and you have to type furiously for your life.

I really like the battle system. It actually requires a bit of thinking in addition to the typing, since you have up to 4 magic types that you can switch between (by typing their names) in battle. Some magics do damage over time, some do AOE damage, and some provide great crowd control. So depending on whether you're fighting a horde of tiny bugs with a few 4 letter words to type each or huge "tanks" with massive words you want to use a different strategy.

The puzzles and dungeons, while kind of basic compared to games like Zelda, are varied, fun, and gorgeous. I've beaten 6/8 of the dungeons and there were plenty new themes and mechanics that got thrown at me so I was never bored.

So yeah, highly recommended.

23116070.review:
This is hands down the best typing game I have played, my experience with others in the learning to type genre is that they are typically tedious and boring and so, until now I had no idea you could actually *enjoy* typing games.

But for complete beginners,  this game does not provide foundations to touch typing, no indicators telling you which fingers to use and key locations etc, best to learn the basics first (There are many great websites for this)
 
Epistory brings new life to the genre of typing games but even holds up on its own as a fun and beautiful game, feels like I’m not even learning to type but playing an adventure rpg with the entire keyboard as my controller.

Beautiful soundtrack too!

[h1]Игра, в которой положительно буквально всё[/h1]

Вы - маленькая девочка, которая скачет верхом на трёхвостой лисице. Вы ничего не помните о себе, не понимаете, где вы, и почему мир вокруг таков, каков он есть. Взаимодействовать с миром нужно путём набора слов на клавиатуре, будь то препятствие, сундук с сокровищем или враг. На пути встретятся и слабые и сильные враги, великолепные локации, подземелья и головоломки. Скучно не будет. Концовка очень трогательная.

22870938.review:
Review Completo: http://criticalhits.com.br/epistory-typing-chronicles-review/

Epistory – Typing Chronicles é aquele jogo que apaixona pela simplicidade, que consegue unir aspectos como história, visual, desafio e diversão com digitação. Ele possui duas histórias diferentes que se entrelaçam durante a jogatina e enquanto escrevemos uma descobrimos a outra. Para escrevermos a história que estamos jogando, Epistory se utiliza da metáfora de que as palavras que utilizamos para derrotar os insetos que empesteiam The Bridge são fornecidas à escritora que assim continua a escrever nossa aventura.

O game tem um visual incrível, deslumbrante, de cair o queixo e carrega um nível de detalhes que se estende até a escolha das palavras. Seu gameplay é bem desafiador e ele possui um sistema de dificuldade adaptativa que muda de acordo com a velocidade que o jogador digita. É uma aventura que vale a pena ser jogada e um diferencial para se ter em sua biblioteca.

Prós:
    Histórias que se entrelaçam
    Visual espetacular
    Nível de detalhes surpreendente
    Gameplay desafiador
    Sistema de dificuldade adaptativa
    Legendas em vários idiomas e suporte a diversos tipos de teclados
    Aborda a digitação de maneira inovadora

Contras:
    Movimentação é frustrante às vezes
    História da escritora deixa um pouco a desejar

[url=http://www.the-backlog.net/epistory-typing-chronicles-review/]My full review can be found on here.[/url]

One of the first things I fell in love with when I saw Epistory was the graphics. Setting into the unwritten world, seeing it unfold as I play, it was an absolute blast. The story is beautifully written, and as someone who really enjoys "artsy" kinds of games, the game felt all together quite nice.

Epistory plays out sort of like Bastion mixed with typing action. You'll need to face down hordes of insects to unravel the story. 22759423.review:
My mother was a teacher for over thirty years. She was also ran the disadvantaged schools program for a significant part of her career. As such she was constantly pushing that the schools in her area had access to the latest technology and programs available. As an only child I was always close to her. I took an avid interest in her interests. I took an interest in her work. I’ve sustained friendships with a few of her colleagues long after she has passed away. They understand that one of my passions as an adult has been to incorporate gaming into education. One of the important programs that Steamified is in the midst of establishing is based wholly around this ideology. As such those friends have helped keep me up to date on the latest and greatest games that can be used for educational purposes. I’ve played most of the ones that I’ve been able to get my hands on. Therefore my credentials of understanding this specific genre of gaming is well grounded.

With that said I want to tell you that I have never found a game as good as Epistory: Typing Chronicles to educate school aged gamers to learn to type. I’ve played games such as The Typing of the Dead: Overkill, the legendary Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing and countless others. While they’re all very good games for various reasons they don’t match up as wholly well as what Epistory does. The game’s features and its story are so well executed that the learning experience that is available within the game is one that can be easily hidden. That’s part of what makes the game so special from that perspective. The best learning experiences are those where the student isn’t concentrating on the actual learning but the actual experience. An analogy to that is the best way to teach someone how to read isn’t by having them read the dictionary but rather through reading the types of material that they enjoy the most. You learn to type through the game by being engrossed into the game, its story and by enjoying its features. The player does not have their mind focused on the actual typing but rather the destruction of enemies and of eliminating pieces of the environment that need to be cleared in order to progress. In this essence, Epistory is almost completely flawless.

Don’t allow me to pigeon hole the game as one for the kids because there is plenty here for adults to enjoy as well. As a game it is exciting and constantly challenging. The story is engrossing and the atmosphere is engaging. The game’s puzzles beyond the typing are intuitive and have been very well designed and implemented into the game. The paper craft world is among the most fascinating and beautiful that I have come across. I love how the graphics display the world opening up to the player. One of the game’s greatest strengths are the sheer amount of keyboard and language options. There are seven languages and seven keyboard options.

Fishing Cactus have added Steam achievements to their game as well as incorporating Steam Workshop and Steam Leaderboard tools. I would naturally love to see trading cards added to the game as it would be one of those games where I just have to level it up to level 5. Within the game I would like to see the ability to reset upgrade points implemented into the game. However, that would enable players to unlock multiple achievements without much effort. Another thing that I would like to see added is the ability to have different save profiles. I’d love to have Ainslie play the game but the game is on my account and to allow her to do so – without family sharing – is to have her play my save game which is something that I would like to avoid.

That this is the Steam debut of Fishing Catcus makes Epistory an even more remarkable achievement. It’s a game that I would dearly love to see spawn a sequel as it is such an easy recommendation that it will likely find itself among my favorite games of this year. At $14.99 this game is already a bargain.

For more reviews and our popular giveaways please visit [url=http://www.steamified.com]Steamified.com[/url].

22635458.review: Eindelijk weer eens een spel waar ik wordt beloond voor het feit dat ik mezelf jaren geleden blind heb leren typen. Dat soort spellen zijn er niet veel en ze zijn ook lang niet altijd goed of leuk. Maar Epistory zit goed in elkaar en verveelt niet snel. Het spel heeft een prachtige 'papercraft' uitstraling, alsof de hele wereld gemaakt is van gevouwen papier. Snel en nauwkeurig typen wordt beloond, maar je wordt niet genadeloos afgestraft als je een typefout maakt. Door vijanden te verslaan, verdien je punten die je kunt gebruiken om verbeteringen te kopen, zoals: sneller lopen, teleporteren naar poorten die je al hebt geopend en allerlei bonussen die je typeaanvallen sterker maken. In de verschillende regio's van het spel vindt je ook nieuwe spreuken (eerst vuur en vervolgens ijs), waarmee je obstakels kunt verwijderen (braamstruiken verbranden of water bevriezen) en je nieuwe gebieden kunt bereiken. Er is een goede afwisseling van het oplossen van puzzels, het ontdekken van geheime kamers, het vinden van buit en het vechten tegen vijanden. In het begin is het even wennen om je personage te besturen met de E F en J I toetsen (traditionele besturing met WASD of pijltjestoetsen is ook mogelijk), maar dit wende bij mij snel. Terwijl de wereld zich rondom jou ontvouwt, vertelt een prettige vrouwenstem je over de wereld om je heen en jouw rol in het bijzonder. Het doet een beetje denken aan de manier waarop dit in Bastion gebeurde. Verder deed Epistory me denken aan het spel Okami, dat ik jaren geleden op de PS2 speelde. Daarin speelde je een magische vos in een door Japanse waterverftekeningen geïnspireerde wereld die met haar staart kon tekenen en zo de wereld om haar heen kon beïnvloeden. Epistory heeft vergelijkbare elementen, zonder dat het een rechtstreekse kopie is. Als action RPG's, typespellen of spellen als Okami je aanspreken, zul je je niet vervelen met Epistory. Om kort te gaan: zeer de moeite waard.

22625358.review:
[h1]Epistory: Typing Chronicles – A Steam Review[/h1]

[i][Disclamer - I was provided a copy by the publisher for review purposes][/i]

[b]The good[/b]

[list]
[*]Interesting mechanic where you type commands in combat and exploration
[*]Great game to expand your vocabulary and improve your typing speed
[*]Good voiceover and music
[*]Gorgeous world and map revealing animations
[/list]

[b]The not so good: [/b]

[list]
[*]Story is a bit meh
[*]Found a bug one hour in and couldn't progress any further (quickly patched though)
[/list]

[b]The conclusion: [/b]

An action-adventure where you type words to destroy objects and enemies, Typing Chronicles doesn't require a mouse or a controller. It's a very interesting project and is sure to challenge you - I thought I typed fast but some of the arenas were quite a challenge.
After an hour and a half I reached a point where I couldn't progress any further but I understand that bug is now fixed. I look forward to playing it again, it's actually a very educational experience: for example, the fire spell makes you type dozens of words in that semantic field. Wonderful game for kids (learn new words and type fast!), decent adventure and a challenge for older folks. The story however is very generic fantasy, so I can't say much about it.

All in all, I recommend you give it a try.

22584732.review:
Une vraie perle, une petite pépite à n'absolument pas louper.

+ Le gameplay est très novateur et extrêmement attractif, j'irai jusqu'à dire visionnaire.
+ L'univers est un joli indé bien fait, avec de beaux graphismes, des mondes magnifiques
+ Il y a même un mode "compétitif" (mode Arène) 
+ Un très bon système de bug report (le jeu sort tout juste de l'accès anticipé) et une super communication avec l'équipe
+ Un jeu qui continue à s'autocorriger (certains jeux une fois sortis se foutent des bugs restants) avec perfectionnisme
+ La traduction française est parfaite, fluide et vraiment au point, pas du tout bâclée
+ Des cartes/badges et des succès (très bien trouvés d'ailleurs haha. Par exemple, au bout de 4 550 mots tapés on débloque : "1% du Seigneur des anneaux")

- La durée de vie du mode histoire est limitée (6-7h max), même si je trouve que ça vaut toujours le coup
- Dès qu'on baisse la qualité des graphismes (pour que le jeu soit plus fluide quand on fait tourner autre chose à côté) cela nuit au gameplay car on ne voit pas toujours les ennemis correctement

En conclusion, c'est un vrai petit bijou qui vaut son prix, que vous soyez un simple curieux, ou un véritable amateur de jeux indés, je vous le recommande très fortement <3

22540514.review:
[h1][Оценка в блоге 9.3 балла][/h1]

Способен ли тренажер для скоростной печати быть интересным на протяжении многих часов подряд? Я думаю, сомнительно, с другой стороны, если к этому жанру отнести Epistory — Typing Chronicles без всяких лишних определений, то подобный тренажер может затянуть. Но без красочных слов тут не обойтись.

Epistory это не просто печатный тир, это настоящее приключение пропитанное атмосферой сказки. Мы в роли музы верхом на сказочном лисе исследуем бумажный мир. Тоскливый, но приятный голос рассказывает о мире, который мы постепенно открываем. Прежде чем двинуться дальше мы слышим и видим, как вырисовываются слова истории. Грубо говоря, приключение мы начинаем с чистого листа и чем дальше мы заходим, чем больше открываем, тем интереснее и захватывающее становится история, которая пишется на ходу. Предложение одно за другим наслаивается друг на друга и перед глазами вырисовывается картина происходящего, голос не умолкает даже тогда, когда идет пылкая борьба с чудищами. Чтобы мы ничего не упустили все сказанное проецируется на земле рядом с нами.

Сказочный мир оригами — так разработчики назвали окружающие нас декорации. На самом деле визуальная составляющая один из ключевых элементов Epistory — Typing Chronicles, так как мир полностью имитирует модели из бумаги. Земля и моря сотканы из тысяч бумажных кип, горы, стены и леса — все из бумаги, даже эффекты вроде огня, воды и тому подобное все воспроизведено с помощью «оригами».

Раз уж речь зашла о ключевых моментах, то стоит упомянуть о другой немаловажной составляющей, я бы даже сказал, что этот пункт должен стоять самым первым. Epistory — Typing Chronicles — это завуалированный тренажер скоростной печати. Благодаря переводу на несколько языков, то попробовать себя можно сразу по нескольким профилям. В конечно счете тут все завязано на быстром стуке по клавишам. Убрать препятствие, открыть дверь или разгадать несложную головоломку — печатай текст, который висит над этими предметами. Открыть сундук — печатай. Убить врага — печатай. Убить волны врагов — очень быстро и внимательно печатай. За каждое заполненное слово мы получаем очки опыта, чем больше слов подряд, тем больше опыта. На эти очки мы открываем новые локации и получаем навыки. Последние нам помогают легче расправляться с врагами и в целом чувствовать себя немного поуверенее.

В Epistory — Typing Chronicles кроме самой механики печатай, чтобы играть, есть и функции постепенно усложняющие задачу. Это и использование обеих раскладок во время напряженного боя и магия, которая раскрашивает слова и нам нужно успеть переключить с одной стихии на другую и не запутаться. В какой-то момент вы почувствуете себя главным стенографистом всея того места, где вы проживаете.

Подводя итоги, можно смело рекомендовать Epistory — Typing Chronicles как любителям подобной механики, так и новичкам, желающим встретить реальный вызов. В бонус ко всему этому идет отличная сказочная история, стильная и приятная глазу графика.

22528512.review:
As a muse riding a three tailed fox you are slowly creating a world and cleansing it from the corruption that stifled it: everything you do will be done through typing and,as you advance through the game, you'll get stronger while slowly uncovering the story behind your creation.
Epistory is a really nice adventure game with an original and engaging take on the typing genre: there's much to do and see in its finely crafted world and most of it is enjoyable barring a few bugs and possibly frustrating parts.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-lovely art style, zones and objects reveal through a great paper unfolding animation

-nice soundtrack

-a good story featuring two interesting narrative levels

-typing mechanics are spot on

-skill system lets you upgrade your favourite abilities (you'll probably unlock everything before the end 

though)

-a decent sized world with several different "dungeons" to explore and puzzles to solve

-offers a good challenge even on easier difficulty levels

-support for several languages and keyboards lets even non-English speakers enjoy the game

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]

-can be mentally draining when played for an extended period of time due to some frantic fights and instant death

-sound effects work decently but are bland overall

-actual gameplay is very simple and can get a bit dull before the end

-adequate length at 5/6 hours, you also have an arena mode with leaderboards

[b]CONS:[/b]

-a few bugs here and there, some made worse by problematic patches from the devs

-certain fights do up the ante quite a bit and, if you die, having to start over and redo a minute or two of waves can get aggravating

-controls feel slightly clunky when when it comes to precise movements during puzzles

-little variety in enemies

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=668919476

Epistory creates a very charming world, the art style is simply faultless and results in some nice vistas and interesting places to explore. The typing mechanics work well both in fights and during exploration, slowly a little variety is introduced with enemies requiring more than one word, repeating words to activate a lever etc. You'll also unlock different elements that are not only required to solve certain puzzles but also give you tactical options during fights         ( e.g. ice freezes enemies, fire burns out the next word you'd have typed). The game is pretty challenging when facing enemy waves, you're basically rooted on ther spot and have to deal with several waves coming your way: the challenge comes from having to quickly look at words, type them, ensure no new enemies spawn near and- eventually- having to quickly switch elements. And if you die you'll have to do the whole thing again so you can easily imagine how losing a few times in the last wave can get a bit aggravating.

Having to start over on some long and difficult fights during the late game can get downright frustrating to be honest, even more so if you just made a typo or wasn't expecting an enemy to spawn close: the game requires quite a bit of mental focus and good reflexes so prolonged plays can leave you quite drained. Also slightly frustrating were a few puzzles requiring precise movements where I felt the keyboard hadn't enough finesse to make things as smooth as expected.

Last but not least despite being out for almost a month there's still a few bugs, most of them are simply annoying like the map not working in a certain dungeon, an achievement triggering at the wrong time and so on: the 13th April patch introduced a game stopping bug though and, when the devs reverted to the previous patch, experience points where reset for certain players (myself included). I was lucky enough to have enough chests and fights left to go almost go back to where I was (plus an hour or so of grinding the few respawning mobs you find around) but since those points are needed to reveal new areas and progress the situation was pretty dire.

There's not many typing games around and Epistory surely ranks amongst the best: it's a great experience despite a few flaws and fans of the genre, or those looking for novel game mechanics, will find plenty to like. You might want to wait for a few more patches to land though, to ensure things are smooth and nothing breaks again.

22497393.review:
First off, don't be dissuaded by the fact that this is a typing game. It is very much an adventure game with typing for combat. Unless you are absolutely dreadful with the keyboard you should enjoy playing this game. Some of the fights, especially the end of level fights, can be pretty fast-paced, but there is a dynamic difficulty so if you fail a fight it will be easier the next time.

The game itself is beautiful. It has a paper/origami styling in both the graphics and the game sounds and it is wonderfully executed. As you progress through the world you unlock new areas and these flutter and unfold into being in front of your eyes. You gain multiple powers of magic as you explore the different parts of the story/world and these abilities must be used not only to interact with elements of the world but in combat. All combat is against insects ranging from crawling, to walking, to flying bugs. There is nothing gory. The large fights can last several minutes and you are stationary during them while and onslaught constantly spawns around you. There is no penalty for death, you will just restart moments before triggering the fight, but as I mentioned earlier the difficulty of the fight will be reduced. I really like this feature and wish more games would provide it. I'm in the game more for the experience, the story, the exploration, not to perfect combat so it works very well for me. That said I've only died a few times and I'm not a touch-typer. I have my own typing style which has evolved from 30+ years of having computers. 

The developer has done a great job making the powers feel appropriate. You start with the ability to shoot fireballs when you type words but you gain other types of magic as you progress. I'm not going to say what they are because I think unlocking those powers is part of the fun of the game. Not only do the ways the powers work feel appropriate to the type of magic, but the words you'll need to type are related. It is very easy to see by color of the text which type of magic must be used. It is possible this could be a problem for those with color deficiency issues so I'd recommend watching some videos of the game to see before buying.

The game performs very well. I have no trouble maintaining 60fps at 1080p. The music is wonderful.

I've had a great deal of fun with this game and would highly recommend it.

If you'd like to watch my complete Let's Play of the game the first episode is here...

https://youtu.be/377ghgYOoQo

22457674.review: What a beautiful idea and marvelous execution. Relaxing, engaging story, music and voice acting are spot-on. <3 the art style.

22449136.review:
Традиционно полная версия не влезла, но спешите видеть - http://www.vgblogs.ru/2016/04/epistory-typing-chronicles-mnenie.html

Если описывать механику тезисно и сухо, то может показаться, что это обыкновенный клавиатурный тренажёр, замаскированный под грустную и лирическую сказку. Действительно, на протяжении примерно десяти часов вам придётся безжалостно терзать клавиатуру, раз уж большинство ситуаций в игре завязаны на набор слов. Например, чтобы открыть какую-нибудь дверь необходимо найти условный рычаг, включить режим ввода и оттарабанить нужные буковки. Допустим, "рычаг". Разумеется, это были бы самые примитивные и прямолинейные загадки на свете. Но нечто похожее встречается разве что в самом начале. Затем формула многократно усложняется.

Сражаться с врагами приходится тем же методом. С той оговоркой, что если "затарабанить" до смерти рядовых противников, случайно преградивших путь, не представляет особой сложности (знай себе стучи всплывающие "дол", "червь", "хрен" до победного), то вот зачистка гнёзд вредоносных насекомых то ещё испытание на прочность и внимательность. Стоит вам очутиться в круге, как со всех сторон начинают наступать чудовища. Иногда они атакуют одновременно, порой дают немножко передохнуть и выползают-прилетают поодиночке. И в эти тяжкие минуты приходится судорожно комбинировать разные стихии (огонь, лёд, искру и ветер), внимательно следить, чтобы какой-нибудь мелкий и шустрый гад не подобрался достаточно близко, чтобы атаковать. Поскольку Муза погибает после одного лишь прикосновения порчи, приходится "сканировать" весь экран разом и судорожно набирать слова. Во время затяжных боёв авторы даже не позволяют поставить игру на паузу и спокойно вздохнуть - хардкор в чистом виде!

Наверное вы уже догадались, что встречаются не только стандартные, достаточно хилые противники, но и аналоги боссов. Какие-то огромные чудовища восприимчивы только к атаке конкретной стихией и игнорирую остальные, некоторых тварей приходится атаковать огромными словами - вроде "сенсуальности" или "морозостойкости".

Но сражения - это далеко не основная часть игры. Доведётся исследовать локации в поисках секретов, кладов и упоминавшихся стихий (магические силы сходу просто так не дают), решать головоломки, зачастую не самые очевидные и простые. Не обошлось и без привычного накопительства очков опыта: без них не получится прокачать способности и базовые характеристики Музы, и не позволят продвинуться дальше по сюжету. Так что стоит применять силу слов везде, где есть такая возможность, и не упускать шанса посадить цветок, разрушить кусок горной породы или зажечь огонь в специальной урне.

И не была бы Epistory - Typing Chronicles настоящей игрой про муки творчества, если бы процесс сочинения не отражался на окружающей реальности. С этим здесь всё замечательно: стоит сделать пару шагов в бумажном мире, и писательница своевременно опишет происходящее, наполнит смыслом ваши поступки, или подскажет, что делать дальше. Буквы появляются прямо под ногами, всплывают в самых неожиданных местах, шуршат за спиной... Куски мира вырастают из пустоты, горы и леса складываются из листов бумаги. Вы регулярно становитесь свидетелем рождения реальности из пустоты, и от этого захватывает дух.

Главы игры, которые ещё предстоит отыскать - это не просто череда загадок, сбор сокровищ, поиск правильного пути и охапка сражений с насекомыми. Скорее их можно назвать метафоричным переложением событий из жизни безымянной героини, неторопливо исследующей собственный внутренний мир. Неслучайно вокруг разбросаны коллекционные предметы, необходимые для материализации фотографий из прошлого. И довольно часто разработчики ломают четвёртую стену. Но делают это элегантно и ненавязчиво - без ухмылок. подмигиваний и прочих сомнительных способов привлечь внимание.

Единственная мысль, посетившая меня во время просмотра финальных титров: благодаря таким произведениям игры, возможно, когда-нибудь и признают полноценным видом искусства. Без всяких скидок, поправок и уточнений. Epistory - Typing Chronicles может похвастаться не только картинкой фантастической красоты, полной мелких деталей, отличной музыкой, и до блеска отполированной механикой, но и богатым смысловым наполнением. Далеко не факт, что полная картина легко и просто сложится в голове по итогу. Но над метафорами и гиперболами Fishing Cactus очень приятно поразмыслить на досуге.

Дисклеймер: ревью-код

22406812.review:
Remember the good old days of learning to touch type? Personally I had heaps of fun learning to touch type and I’d even try and find games that encouraged touch typing. Then I found Typing of the Dead. But sadly that was ages ago. But thankfully, after so many years my prayers have been answered with Epistory Typing Chronicles! Check out our Epistory Typing Chronicles gameplay and review video on YouTube below!

[url=http://gamereviewsau.com/epistory-typing-chronicles-gameplay-and-review/]GameReviewsAU Gameplay and Review Video[/url]

[h1]A Quick Gist[/h1]

Set in a fantasy world filled with monsters, magic and a giant fox, Epistory: Typing Chronicles takes you on a mysterious journey through a world that literally lays itself out before you.

Explore dungeons, solve puzzles and take on masses of monsters that require you type words in order to defeat them. Epistory is not for the faint hearted and will certainly put your typing skills to the test. There are heaps of areas to explore, treasure chests to find and puzzles to solve.

Manipulate certain elements with your typing, such as fire, ice, lightning or wind. Each element provides you with advantages to sort out your foes. For example, when activating ice, your enemies will stop in their tracks when you hit them with a word. Fire will burn the next word to appear so you don’t have to type it, and so on.

Whether you’re a two-finger typist or a profesh touch typist, there’s room to accommodate your play style with the differing levels of difficulty.

Epistory: Typing Chronicles is simply incredible and such a breath of fresh air. I haven’t played a game this unique for a very long time and I thank the team at Fishing Cactus for bringing us such a magnificent game. Hope to see more coming from their studios in the future!

22389356.review:
[h1]Ich habe vom Entwickler einen Key erhalten, was mein Review allerdings nicht beeinträchtigt.[/h1]

Wow, dieses Spiel hat mich eiskalt erwischt. 
Epistory - Typing Chronicles ist ein Schreibmaschinen-Simulator :) man läuft in einer wirklich wunderschönen Welt herum und zerstört Gegner und Objekte, indem man bestimmte Wörter tippt.
Das Spiel kann auch komplett in deutscher Sprache gespielt werden. Ob es dadurch schwieriger als auf englisch wird, kann ich nicht beurteilen (durch Umlaute und ähnliches).

[h1]Grafik:[/h1]
Das Spiel wird in einer Iso-Perspektive gespielt und läuft butterweich.
Der Grafikstil erinnert mich dabei ein wenig an Tearaway, es sieht aus, als wäre die Welt aus bunten gefaltenen Papierstücken zusammengesetzt. Dies wird so stilsicher umgesetzt, dass die Welt einfach aus einem Guss wirkt und dies durch diverse Effekte (z.B. wenn sich die Welt "erweitert", falten sich unzählige kleine Papierstücke auf und neue Teile und Wege entstehen) kräftig unterstützt wird. 

[h1]Sound:[/h1]
Der Sound passt wunderbar ins Spiel, es herrscht öfters ruhige Stimmung, wenn sich allerdings größere Kämpfe anbahnen, ändert sich die Hintergrundmusik dementsprechend. Sehr schön gemacht!

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Ich würde das Spiel grundsätzlich als Iso-Exploration Spiel mit Kämpfen und Rätseln ansehen. Man kann durch Drücken der Leertaste in den sogenannten Schreibmodus wechseln und falls sich Objekte oder Monster am Schirm befinden, erscheint über diesen ein oder mehrere Wörter, die man dann einfach eintippen muss. Dies gestaltet sich so problemlos und funktioniert so gut, dass man bald Horden von Gegnern niedermetzelt. Im späteren Spielverlauf kommen immer wieder neue Elemente wie z.B. Feuer (verbrennt Gegner langsam) oder Eis (friert Gegner eine gewisse Zeit lang ein) hinzu und man kann seine Fähigkeiten verbessern. Sogar die Menüsteuerung funktioniert, indem man die Wörter (z.B. "Karte") einfach eintippt.

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Mich hat das Spiel total umgehauen! Es wirkt wie aus einem Guss und man übt nebenbei das Tippen auf der Tastatur :)
Für mich eine klare Kaufempfehlung!

22369986.review:
Epistory is a simple action/adventure game where you type words to attack enemies. Which is AWESOME. I am very much a fan of typing games, having put many hours into games like Typing of the Dead (the original Dreamcast version and TotD: Overkill on Steam) or the online competitive typing game TypeRacer; Epistory is one of the best in the genre.

Besides just attacking enemies by typing the words above them, you also collect four elemental powers through the game that you switch between by just literally typing out the word - "fire" "ice" "spark" or "wind". Each elemental power has different effects on enemies (freezing them, blowing them back, etc.) and some enemies can only be defeated by certain elements, so you sometimes have to switch quickly. It adds a really nice extra layer of strategy and multitasking to an already fun concept. 

The game scales up fairly well with typing speed - there are 3 difficulty levels (I played on the hardest difficulty). For normal typing I average around 120 WPM, and while it was never particularly difficult to beat the levels, it was challenging enough to be fun. There's not really any penalty for typos, it just discards them rather than making you backspace. 

One of the most fun modes (especially if you're a fast touch typist) is the endless "Arena" mode where you try to get a high score with progressively harder enemies. It eventually gets to the point where your hands are flying over the keys in a frantic attempt to keep the enemy hordes at bay, and it definitely gets exciting. This mode even includes online leaderboards, which is a nice touch.

If you enjoy typing games, or you're trying to improve your touch typing skills, learn a new keyboard layout, or you just want something to test out your shiny new clickity clacky mechanical keyboard on, this game scratches an itch that few other games do. I highly recommend it.

22363511.review:
Das letzte Spiel, an das ich mich noch erinnern kann, bei dem man wirklich eine Tastatur brauchte, war der zweite "Roger Wilco"-Teil gewesen, bei dem man seinerzeit noch mittels eines Textparser(!) die Rätsel löste, deren Lösungen dann gern so aussahen: "stick gem into mouth". Irgendwie vermisse ich das.

Ich hab mir schon früh selbst einen schnellen 8-Finger-Tippstil antrainiert und schaue nur noch gelegentlich auf die Tastatur, von daher hatte ich keine Scheu, hier gleich zuzuschlagen. Die Idee, die ganze Tastatur mal wirklich als notwendiges Steuerelement für ein Spiel einzusetzen, ist schon ziemlich frech wie genial. Trotzdem hat es mich zu Anfang echt fast in die Raserei getrieben, denn bislang hielt ich nie etwas von "dynamischer Schweregrad-Anpassung". Wirklich jedes Spiel, bei dem das angeboten wurde, wurde daraufhin so schwer für mich, dass ich schnell den Spaß verlor. Ausgerechnet hier scheint es aber mal sinnvoll zu funktionieren - ohne diese Einstellung werden die "Bosskämpfe" nämlich gleich von Anfang an recht hart und für Leute, die nach dem Adler-Such-System tippen, schlicht unschaffbar. Andererseits kam es mir mit dynamischen Schweregrad dann doch teils wieder zu einfach vor. Es ist eben vertrackt, den Sweatspot zwischen Frust und anspornender Herausforderung zu treffen.

Auf der anderen Seite punktet das Spiel noch mit einer wirklich liebevoll und kreativ gestalteten Welt, die sich makellos, reizvoll und ganz dem Thema entsprechend zeigt. An der Stelle haben die Entwickler auch nichts anbrennen lassen, es macht Spaß und man möchte mehr sehen/entdecken. Schön eingesetzt sind auch Kamerafahrten, man schaut nicht durchgängig aus derselben isometrischen Perspektive auf das Geschehen. Hier versteht jemand sein Handwerk.

Das ganze für schlappe 15 EUR ist dann oben drein quasi geschenkt. Also, wer sich ein wenig was zu traut oder vielleicht sogar eine unterhaltsame Methode sucht, schneller Tippen zu lernen, sollte hier nicht lange zögern. Insgesamt ist das Gameplay eher entspannend, wenn man sich etwas Zeit nimmt und nicht gleich von Bosskampf zu Bosskampf durchdonnert. Wichtig bei diesen ist dann die Angriffstypen zu verstehen, die man nach und nach bekommt.

Insgesamt ein wirklich origineller Titel, der wirklich den ein und anderen Award verdient hat.

22316670.review:
Игра вышла, а деньги на её покупку появились только сегодня, и меня одолевали сомнения стоит ли её брать, но набравшись храбрости (и начитавшись про системы возвратов в стиме) решился и взял её... и не пожалел ни капли
Даже с моим скоростным печатанием вслепую я умудряюсь потеть и иногда проигрывать, потому что, порой, просто долбить слова в ней не получается. Точнее, в 3-й главе появляются сложности, причём конкретные (не буду раскрывать всех секретов, пусть будет сюрпризом.
Дизайн игры великолепный. Эти все бумажные ландшафты, бумажная героиня и её лис, это смотрится по-простецки прекрасно и гармонично. Мы попадаем в прекрасную сказку, и когда ты вбиваешь очередное слово, складывается ощущение что ты сам её и пишешь.
Саундтрек игры тоже великолепен, он точно отражает то, что происходит или будет происходить дальше. А когда просто бежишь вперёд навстречу чему-то новому музыка приятно успокаивает и даёт отдохнуть.
"Нестандартное" управление подобрано просто отлично. Можно, конечно, пользоваться стандартным WASD или стрелочками, причём без захода в настройки (что, несомненно, лишний плюс), но с "родным" управлением легче переключиться на ввод очередного слова. По началу управление будет непривычным, и вы будете путаться, но затем вы привыкнете и освоитесь.
Теперь о минусах. Их у игры один. 
Не знаю почему, но если встречается однобуквенный враг или очередной сундук, то игра просто требует переключение раскладки. Конечно, переключить не составляет сложности, но всё же порой не привычно и в бою мозги просто плавятся. Приятно так плавятся, но думаю не всем это по душе.
В общем, если хотите научиться быстро печатать вслепую, то вам придётся попотеть, но вы добьётесь своей цели. Если вы просто любите игры такого жанра, вам понравится эта игра. Если вы любите красивые истории, вы найдёте её здесь. Даже если ни один из вышеперечисленных пунктов вам не подходит, стоит просто присмотреться к этой игре, взять её и хотя бы попробовать, и если уж за 1-1,5 часа вам она покажется не по душе, можете вернуть свои деньги по системе возврата.

22310126.review:
A typing game unlike most.  This game is a gorgeous work of art - the isometric-view world looks like hand-crafted origami, and you guide a dreaming girl through it on her quick, brown fox.  (Yes.  That old gag.)

The narrative is a heavy-handed metaphor for a woman trying to convey how much inner strength is required to simply navigate the real world.  Each distinct and vibrant area you navigate your fox-riding author-avatar through represents the (traumatic) memory of phases of her life, whose mercifully-vague resolutions bring empowerment and... Whatever. You can easily ignore the breathless gushing of bad poetry and author catharsis to focus on the mechanics of typing to solve puzzles and kill insects.  

The story might be one developer's alternative to expensive therapy, but we got a fantastic game out of it.  Different types of obstacle require different types of unlocked 'powers', allowing for that metroid style back-tracking fun.  Chaining together quick combos increases your exp generation, which affords you more upgrades to your typing power abilities and provides incentive to push forward swiftly, thoroughly typing at anything that moves.

I strongly recommend this game for typing fans.  It's novel, gorgeous, and has an incredibly solid variety of tricks to spice up the otherwise simple experience of typing as fast as you can.

22273081.review:
A fun game with some pretty nifty graphics and interesting mechanics. There are some minor gameplay issues, mostly to do with knocking enemies so far back that their target words disappear, but on the whole the strategic facets of combat and the absolutely absurd vocabulary more than make up for them. If you're looking for a typing game that aspires to be more than simply 'type the words on the screen,' this is it. I heartily recommend Epistory for the elemental combat mechanics, and for trying to reinvent a genre that never really tried to be more than pressing buttons.

The only real negative is the story - what little there is of it. The plot is lazy and angsty, mostly boiling down to 'Oh no, I'm so lost and alone,' and the writer has definitely attended the Academy of Vague. Most every line suggests that the character is trying to do [u]something[/u], but the continual lack of coherent progress kills the sense of mystery, and after a half hour or so I found myself just wanting our hero to be quiet and let me play. Alone, got it. Lost, got it. Feeling an urge to  reach XYZ for no reason, got it. The ending is disappointing and offers little real resolution; unfortunately that puts it entirely on par with what you're offered on your way through the game. Still, typing, right?

Graphics: Really nice (Stylized, not really cartoonish)

Sound: Immersive

Gameplay: You play entirely with the keyboard.  Movement is done with the keys, but not the standard WASD movement.  It makes you keep your hands in the typing position.  I've always thought of myself as a decent typer, as I do a lot of written documentation.  But the unusual words that you have to type under pressure really challenge your keyboard skills.  I didn't realize how sloppy some of my typing was until some of the bigger boss battles (I'm looking at you, letter P).

It's quickly becoming my favorite current game, which I find surprising.  My one complaint is that I don't see a way to have a second game saved.  I'd love to have someone else in the family play it also.

22265442.review:
同样是打字杀怪的游戏，Epistory-Typing Chronicles和The Typing of the dead:Overkill在风格上完全是两个极端。
死亡打字员充满了各种B级片桥段，各种血腥暴力，污言秽语，恶搞幽默，Cult味儿十足。
而这款游戏则是不折不扣的小清新，折纸风格的游戏场景，蓝天白云，绿树红花，以及萌萌的女主角和她的狐狸坐骑。

但是不要被小清新的画风蒙蔽了！这依然是一款能让你郁闷到砸键盘的打字游戏，每一关都有一处要对付潮水般涌来的敌人，你一边手忙脚乱的输入单词，同时还要眼观全局，按合理的顺序处理高速接近的小怪和缓慢移动的大怪，一旦死了就要从记录点重来。

本作的难度绝对是高于死亡打字员的，死亡打字员死了可以不停的续命，从你死的那个瞬间继续打下去，续命后敌人的血量也是你之前打掉的程度，而本作在怪物潮阶段死了就要从重新来过，更可怕的是本作主角脆弱得一碰就死……

但是不要因为本作的难度就放弃它，作为一个对自己有要求的上进青年，你怎么能容忍自己多年未纠正的错误打字手势和缓慢的输入速度呢？

22244501.review:
Epistory is, at it's heart, a cute game with an unravelling story. The core mechanic relies on typing: obstacles, puzzles and enemies are overcome by typing. But the game is so much deeper than that.

The level design is just brilliant. Even the seemingly random words you type hold part of the story. Lots of play on words and fun puzzles reinforce the entire world, perfecting the core mechanic.

Enemies are fun to type away, and there are four elements you can use (once you've mastered them) each with different results, giving you a varied gameplay experience and your own personal choice for combat (most of the time, anyway).

The story itself is nice. I can't really say much more without any spoilers, but I found it very enjoyable. Add the fact that world itself is telling part of it, a great voice actress, and a well-thought presentation, and you've got yourself a very fun and interesting joruney.

The game is very well paced, and it's neither too short nor too long. The progression system is neat, and unravelling the world (and the plot) feels very gratifying.

Then there's challenges for those who like to explore the game, and those who want to improve their typing skills. Hidden treasures and parts of the map, plus very cleverly thought out mechanics, and this game is a gem among a lot of mud.

As a final touch, you have the option (on by default) to use adaptive difficulty, which is a great way of not interrupting the flow of the game if you're distracted / having a bad day.

I heartily recommend this game for anyone who's looking for a fun, different game, that doesn't hold your hand through every step or insults your intelligence by making everything too easy / obvious. 

Great job, Fishing Cactus!

22241201.review:
WARNING: I'm a salty old man who drinks too much and hates idealistic youngsters.

I'm not quite sure who this game is for. The narrative seems like it was written by a special snowflake reflecting on her life and trying to tell the tale of growing up and the stresses of childhood vs those of adulthood through not subtle enough metaphor. The subject matter seems kid friendly at first, which makes me think this might be a good tool for teaching a daughter how to type, but by the time I'd want a child to start tackling topics like heart break and social pressure, I'd hope I'd have already taught her qwerty typing. As cautionary advice from someone who's been there, it falls flat again. The story reads like it was written by a young woman (mid to late 20s) fresh out of a tumultous time in her life (college and a couple relationships) with words of wisdom and reassurance for the younger people behind her. When the author gets a little older, she'll look back on the age she is now and realize she didn't know anything yet.

As an adult who can type, It's not terribly useful as a keyboarding instructional tool. There doesn't seem to be any way to up the difficulty to a set number of wpm and I'm not sure how well that'd work anyway. The game is entertaining enough, but the challenge portions get frustrating when 1 letter enemies come flying in and break up your flow. If I'm spelling vexation for instance, and a little thing attacks that requires me to type an x, often the game will think I misspelt vexation or it won't count it towards the word I was typing (making the correct solution to type vexxation). In any event, it is rather vexing.

I am intrigued by the language option. Will there be updates to allow me type in Spanish? That could be interesting. Hearing the dialogue in a language I don't speak would be nice too, only way it'd be new or original.

Visually, the game is appealing, if simplistic. The puzzles are clearly influenced by and seem like a simpler version of Legend of Zelda puzzles. The camera style is reminiscent of Bastion (a good thing). The music (where present) is well suited to the gameplay, though a bit more on the overworld map wouldn't have gone amiss.

Overall, it gets a recommendation, but only just, and only because the technical aspects of the game are pulled off mostly with some style and competently enough even in the rough spots. It's games like this that make me long for a third, neutral rating option. Sort of a wavy hand icon, as if to say "meh."

If you're looking for top down zelda esque game with strong narration and real life overtones, play Bastion. If you want a keyboarding program disguised as a game, Typing of the Dead is still a better buy for sheer customization options.

If you're trying to teach a youngster to type with a game, slap yourself. Then see if you can find an MSDOS copy of Reader Rabbit. Sure it's old, but you should be teaching a child to type at an age where they can't appreciate the difference between a 7 core souped up PC or a floppy disk IBM anyway, and besides, it's a better teaching tool.

If you want a more laid back, zombie-less keyboarding game with modern, but indie touched graphics and overtones of "childhood flowing into adult problems" vibe going for it, I guess this is your game. 

All 8 of you young ladies in the feminist / early education / computer club at your local community college will love it.

22240433.review:
[h1]Ich habe den Key vom Entwickler zu Reviewzwecken erhalten, was jedoch nicht meine Meinung beeinflusst[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Bei Epistory handelt es sich um ein Typing Game gemixt mit etwas Action Adventure und einer schönen Story und Grafik
Das Gameplay selbst ist eigentlich recht einfach erklärt. man reitet auf einem Fuchs durch eine riesige Welt welche jedoch anfangs nur teilweise betretbar ist. Alle Interaktionen laufen über Worte wofür man einen normalen und einen Typing Mode besitzt, das bedeutet im normalen Modus kann man sich bewegen, im Typingmodus kann man schreiben und dadurch interaktionen ausführen. Interaktionen sind zum Beispiel kämpfen, Truhen öffnen, Objekte zerstören, Objekte aktivieren,....
Anfangs besitzt man nur die weisse Standardkraft mit welcher man nur weisse Texte aktivieren kann, Im späteren Verlauf bekommt man weitere Kräfte wie z.B Feuer, Eis, Blitz,... durch welche man andersfarbige Worte aktivieren kann und welche Fähigkeiten wie brennen oder vereinsen besitzen. Die Worte sieht man nur im Typingmodus und diese stehen über den Objekten, Gegnern.
Mit jeder Interaktion erhält man Punkte durch welche man auflevelt und weitere Gebiete freischaltet.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
- Das Spielsystem ist sehr schön aufgebaut
- Schöne grafik
- Gute Erzählerinnengeschichte
- Wird gut erklärt 
- Steamachievements
- man wird tatsächlich im Spiel immer besser im schreiben.


[h1]Neutral[/h1]
- Steuerung könnte etwas besser sein, amn kann leider nur in 8 Richtungen laufen
- Spiel wird im späteren Teil sehr hektisch, hier wäre ein zusätzlicher Modus gut gewesen indem man das SPiel einfach geniessen kann und alles etwas langsamer wäre

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Nur 1 Speicherstand möglich
- Schwierigkeitsgrad sollte einstellbar sein denn für manche Leute ist es nicht weit schaffbar da es schnell anzieht 
- im Deutschen gibt es sehr viele Fachwörter/ Wörter mit z.B "ß", wenn man dann ausversehen mal auf CAPS Lock kommt hat man so gut wie evrloren in einem stressigen Kampf denn bis man das Problem gefunden hat ist der gegner meist schon bei einem.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Ein sehr schönes Typing game bei dem mir leider ein Modus fehlt in dem man die Story und das Spiel einfach nur ruhig geniessen kann, stattdessen ist es leider in den späteren Kämpfen immer sehr hektisch. trotzdem ist es ein wunderschönes Spiel das ich persönlich sehr genossen habe und auch immer wieder genießen werde. Wer auf diese Art von Spielen steht und auch keine Angst hat vor kämpfen in denen man mal 30-40 Wörter in der Minute schaffen muss (Auch Fachwörter und Komplizierte längere Worte) der sollte auf jedenfall zugreifen.



Wenn euch diese Review gefallen hat, dann folgt unserem Reviewprogramm
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/-German_Gamer_Community-

22237316.review:
Found this game by total luck while browsing my Queue.   

Note: If you have to look at your keyboard while typing, this game might not be for you. However, the game has "Adaptive Difficulty Mode". So I'm guessing it start to go easier on you if you do more typos and stuff. I've no idea how exactly how this works.

The game has a narrative style similar to "Bastion", but more like Fantasy and Poems, it's not as involving but add a nice little touch. 

Game play is basically:

1 - Explore the world and unlock new sections
2 - Solve puzzles (They are quite simple)
3 - Destroy obstacles and loot chests
4 - Kill enemies and boss fights. 

All of this is done with your keyboard, there's no mouse input.  Even switching from Fire to Ice spell for example is done by typing "Ice" or "Fire".  Killing enemies is done by typing words.

There's also a light RPG element to it, as you get skill points and can upgrade various things. So it gives a sense of progression which add to the fun. 

I recommend you watch a gameplay on youtube if you're unsure.

I'm bad at writing reviews but this game deserves more than 137 reviews so I had to leave one.

My only complains are clunky controls when trying to solve some of the puzzles, only 1 save slot and max res is 2560x1440 (I use a 3440x1440 monitor), so I've to play it Windowed to prevent stretching.

This one of the best best typing game I've played since Typing of the Dead, and it's also a much more relaxing and atmospheric experience. 

Very pleased with the purchase. 

9/10

22236639.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rkbYDyuGdDU

[U]Epistory est un tiping RPG, KEZAKO?[/U]

Eh bien, vous vous balladez dans un monde fait de couleurs pastels ( le moteur du jeu :UNITY, ce moteur est capables de tant de choses entre les mains d'un bon développeur), vous rencontrez des ennemis que vous devez tuer en...écrivant les mots qui sont au dessus d'eux. Vous voyez TYPING OF THE DEAD? hé bien, c'est ça mais en plus coloré et plus gentillet.

L'histoire d'une fille et de son renard à 3 queues (non, non je ne ferai pas de blagues salaces) qui explorent un monde en proie à la destruction...quelque chose de style.

A chaque mot, un multiplicateur de combot se met en place, plus vous tappez vite, plus votre combo augmente, augmentant ainsi "votre bar de mot". Quand cette barre est remplie, vous gagnez des points de compétences (renard qui se déplace plus vite, combot qui se vide plus lentement...).

Un système de magie est présente: glace, feu tonnerre et vent. Tappez le mot et vos attaques auront un effet de glace, feu, vent... ayant chacun une particularité ( la glace bloque les ennemis...).

LEs mouvement se font au WASD.

Des coffres sont à découvrir qui débloquent des images plutot jolies à collectionner.

Un mode défi classique existe et permet de "scorer" a l'envie, pas trop mon truc mais ça existe.

J'aime beaucoup, on sent que le jeu a été fait avec passion: les graphismes sont superbes, les musiques d'excellente facture quoique rapidement répétitives.

[U]Recommande-je?[/U]

Oui si vous aimez tapper des mots, bon exercice pour apprendre à tapper et apprendre de nouveaux mots. La traduction française est excellente: bon usage des temps, du vocabulaire...
Les graphismes sont enchanteurs et invitent à la balade. 
Les contrôles sont un peu délicats mais c'est dû à mon handicap, j'ai du mal avec le WASD.

Donnez lui sa chance, c'est plus intense que ne laisse penser le genre, quand vous avez 5 ennemis autour de vous et qu'il faut tapper "bureaucratiquement", on transpire.

22228364.review:
I can honestly say I couldn't be happier with this game. I saw it come across steam while searching for new games to play and jumped right in not knowing what to expect. I get a sick pleasure out of typing games and this certainly scratched that itch. What I didn't expect what such a rich and engaging storyline to go along with it. It tells the story and shapes the world around you very similarly to how Bastion did and I think it really works in it's favor. Watching the world unfold around you as you unlock it bit by bit is very rewarding as it unfolds through paper crafting it around you. The environments were unique and felt very well fleshed out with their own personalities and dynamic. The levels weren't difficult to navigate and generally made sense to get around. I found the game just challenging enough without getting overly frustrated. As you progress through the storyline you gain abilities that have various effects on the enemies you are fighting. Each has their own unique playstyle that feels like it gives you the freedom to choose how you want to play. There didn't appear to be one power that was more effective than the others, but just promoted different strategies. There were definitely times where the game forced you to use a specific power to fight the enemies, but instead of feeling bound the game choosing for me, I felt challenged as it would force you to think on your feet quickly to prioritize which enemies you went for as there would often be more than one type of element at a time. There were numerous scenarios where you were fighting enemies in wave like fashion where the game never forced you to use any one element. In terms of story, I felt like I maybe wanted a little bit more out of the ending, however there does appear to be a decent amount of replayability with upping the difficulty and the arena challenges.

Now while I enjoyed this game immensely and would recommend in a heartbeat, but there are things that I experienced that I feel should be talked about. The controls can be rather clunky at times making it difficult to navigate through some of the world. It isn't always clear what is part of the environment you can move through and what isn't. I found a couple instances where I would be working through a timed puzzle and would get stuck on an area that didn't look like it had anything hanging me up which was very frustrating. In terms of the game responding to the words I was typing felt very responsive for the most part, however I did find a couple weird issues on that front as well. There would be times that no matter what I did the words to kill an enemy would never pop up. Also, due to the perspective you are sitting in during fights it can be next to impossible to read the words from enemies very far away. It's not that they aren't popping up, but there is a distinct blur that doesn't get clear until they are basically right infront of you. The pop in of the longer words have presented problems for me as well. I understand that the longer words are supposed to be a challenge, however if a word that is like most of the alphabet long is coming from the right hand side of the screen, I won't be able to begin attempting to type it until the enemy is 5 seconds away from one-shotting me. In those instances I think it would help to zoom out from the arena a bit to give the ability to have a decent attempt at the word. There was a moment I had 3 huge monsters slithering towards me and when the words finally popped in there was a difficulty spike of damn near impossible. In issues with the enemies as well, there are moments where there are tiny flying enemies that only have one letter you have to press to kill them. This is fine through most of the game, however there are environments where you are in the sky or another light colored environment where you can't see the letter due to it blending with the background. The smaller enemies look like general non-threatening flies that add to the environment, so a combination of not seeing the letters pop up and the enemies looking like something that is always buzzing around anyway, led to some frustrating failures 5 minutes into a wave-fight that you have to start all over. My last and final gripe was the map....it never seemed to load correctly. There is no way to scroll through the level on the map and oftentimes it would just show black star-looking field of nothingness. I am sure this is something that can come through on a patch, I just hope it does.

I am excited to see how the arena aspect gets fleshed out. I don't know if the dev's are still working on it, but I think this aspect of the game will give longevity and replayability to it as you can compete against others on a world leaderboard. My only complaint there was that the first playthrough I had on arena was fairly easy and I acheived a high score on the leaderboard. However, the subsquent next times I attempted to play the same arena, the words were IMMENSELY harder and this seems to be due to the adaptive difficulty feature. I think that this feature is helpful in keeping the game at the player's pace, however I don't know the scoreboards are able to distinguish based on difficulty and score. It seems to me you could turn adaptive difficulty off and set it to the easiest difficulty and play the arena just to amass a huge score. This could use a bit of balance if that is the case. 

All in all, despite it's flaws, this game was engaging enough for me to keep playing all the way through to the end and then some. I think the flaws are little tweaks that can be made to improve the game that is already fairly well-polished. The quirks aren't enough to make the game unplayable in any respect. I would like to see more games like this one and maybe even another one in the future by the dev's!

22226207.review:
Usually, when i hear about a typing game, i'm all "meh" about it because most of the time, there's nothing else valuable in the game than the fact that you have to type words.

Epistory is not "meh" at all. It's really pretty and you can just walk around, appreciating the environment, listening the soft music, and just relaxing. And then comes gameplay, which can be pretty intense ! I love the fact that the game can adjust difficulty based on your keyboard mastery. For years i was trying to write without looking at my keyboard, but never found any motivation to do so. This game gave me this motivation, and will help me accomplish it, along with a significant improvement of my typing speed.

Story is nice so far, there is definitely something to learn about this world, and behind the narrator.

Another very important point : I couldn't notice any bug right now. The game runs smoothly and everything seems to work as it should. In a time where we see a lot of half-finished games sold as release versions, i think this is worth mentioning.

So, even if you don't enjoy typing games, i think this one is worth it. And if you're looking for a game to help you with your typing skill, that's even better.

P.S. Devs, thank you SO MUCH for making this game a MULTI5, and thinking about every keyboard configruation that goes with it. Just for that, i love you.

Erst einmal möchte ich mein Lob für dieses Spiel verlauten lassen! Markante und Orignielle Darstellung der Umgebung durch das Origami-Thema, dazu ein sehr ungewöhnliches Kampf- & Interaktionssystem und eine interessante Form die Geschichte zu präsentieren.

[b]Englische Tastatur und dann auf Deutsch spielen[/b] - ist keine gute Idee :D Es werden dann gerne mal Umlaute erwartet... 22212634.review:
Please note the developers did give me this game to review, but will not affect my review in any way.

Epistory - Typing Chronicles is a typing game by heart, but a fantastic game with a beautiful world and great level design is found when you look at its layers.

The graphics of this game look fantastic. Everything from the paper mache/origami feel of the characters to the newspaper look of when the world expands; this game really utilises the Unity engine and gives something that is very unique to this game. Luckily, the graphics aren’t the only thing that makes this game unique.

The gameplay is much more than typing. You will explore the overworld; or as it’s called: “The Bridge”. Here there will be basic monsters to fight which you kill by typing, areas that can only be unlocked through abilities that you acquire as you progress through the game or other areas that has to be unlocked through ‘inspiration points’ which is the RPG element of this game. These points are given through fighting enemies and clearing dungeons.

The dungeons is where the gameplay absolutely shines. The level design is absolutely top notch with them looking simple at start but as you unlock the special ability of that dungeon lots of areas start to open up and it becomes really grand and lively. It feels amazing when you accomplish it. 

Other than using Inspiration Points to unlock new areas you can use them to upgrade your character and get perks such as getting more points at a combo or making a special ability stronger so it is more effective. There is also another part of the gameplay that really focuses on fighting the monsters and this is called ‘Arena’. 

You will find these arenas in dungeons and on the bridge and here you can not move as monsters come at you while you fight back and not let them get to you. While this feature is welcomed and is nice at the start; later on in the game these go on for way too long as instead of raising the intensity of the amount of monsters they just make it longer and it just drags on and becomes a bore.

I found the sound to be a hit and miss. The music is good at times and really works and emphasises on the emotional scenes but at other times it doesn’t really fit with what is happening on screen as there may a really intense moment but laid back light music is playing instead of something intense.

The narration however, is incredible with a really nice narrator telling the story of what is going on. And that leads us to the story, which is about a girl on a fox exploring the world around her but anything that was happening in the story I didn’t pick up as the narrator mainly talked about the environment and describing what the girl was feeling. So the main plot, until the end  was kind of was non-existent, but it doesn’t matter much either as a big story isn’t really needed in an overall relaxing game like this. It’s about the environments and gameplay, and that’s what this game does well. 

By the I finished Epistory, I was in love with the game, even if the execution of this game was a little rough around the edges, all the elements add up to make a memorable and amazing game that shouldn’t be frowned upon just because it’s a typing game. Its unique and I recommend it to anyone willing to experience something different.

I give this game a 4.5/5

Pros:
+Graphics
+Expansive world
+Level design in dungeons
+Narration
+Unique gameplay

Cons:
-Music sometimes misses
-Arena sections go on for too long

-Nominated for the “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award

I knew my highschool keyboarding class would be useful someday.



So the actual review: It's an adventure game that happens to be a typing game. A few minor technical issues, but way less than most indie games and nothing game breaking. I sincerely recommend this and I'll probably play it several times.

22191227.review:
I find this game fascinating. There are many things that drew me to it in the first place - the "origami world" phrase in the description, the entire idea of being the muse for a story, the typing. I tend to surprise people with my typing speed (and I generally don't lose much accuracy when typing fast), so a game where using typing controls when and what you attack seemed perfect.

I love the graphics, the voiceover, the story. The game is about the right combination of challenging and fascinating that even when I die repeatedly, I keep trying several times more. Most of what I have trouble with is steering, though that may be my own fault since I steer with WASD instead of what the game suggested. Even so, I'm still enjoying the game and as far as I can tell, I have a lot left to see.

To me, this is the most oddly compelling game I have played in a long time.

22190742.review: Very unique gameplay. Touching music and narrative. Didn't really get the story, though.

22190315.review:
Generally fun Action-RPG style with a novel typing combat dynamic. 

Don't expect it to teach you to touch type though as there is no punishment for errors and no bonuses for accuracy. The words are also just random and not sentences so you could just mash the keys in the right area to success. It also repeats the same words a lot. 

It has some kind of obscure analogous story about life or sickness or love or growing up or something but I didn't find it engaging. The animation is crisp and well done but felt repetitive and overused by the end. 

Fairly short at about 4 hours worth of gameplay and not very challenging if you're reasonably proficient at typing. I died only twice for a whole play-though and never really felt threatened or under pressure.  It has some simple puzzles and some minimal "questing" but it's mostly a hack and slash but with a typing combat dynamic.

Feel is pretty polished with only a few minor bugs but the lack of some basic features like movement-key remapping makes it still feel a bit beta-ish.

I'd like to see some pvp content or some RPG aspects like items or stats; larger/harder/longer battles/enemies would also be a welcome addition.
